sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are vasants (spring), grīṣmas (summer), varṣās (monsoons), and those which are sharad (autumn), hemantas (pre-winter), and shishiras (winter); these are the six seasons, known as the offspring of the deities.

sloka: yavāgūrodano dadhi samigrāmakāmānnādyakāmendriyakāmatejaskāmānāṃ
translation: Desiring pleasure in sense objects such as tastes in yeast, cream, and yogurt.

sloka: tadyatheṣīkātūlamagnau protaṃ pradūyetaiv~ hāsya sarve pāpmānaḥ pradūyante ya etadevaṃ vidvānagnihotraṃ juhoti ||
translation: "Just as wood burns in a blazing fire, so too do all sinners burn when a knowledgable person performs the agnihotra (a type of Vedic ritual)."

sloka: yatheha kṣudhitā bālā mātaraṃ paryupāsate | ev~ sarvāṇi bhūtānyagnihotramupāsata ityagnihotramupāsata iti ||
translation: Like a hungry child serves her mother, so one should serve all beings; this is called agnihotra (the sacred fire ritual), it is called agnihotra.

sloka: agnayo vai trayī vidyā devayānaḥ panthā gārhapatya ṛk pṛthivī rathantaramanvāhāryapacanaḥ yajurantarikṣaṃ vāmadevyamāhavanīyaḥ sāma suvargo loko bṛhattasmādagnīn paramaṃ vadanti || ||
translation: The threefold knowledge is the path of the gods, Agni is its seer, the Gārhapatya is its Rik verse, earth its carriage; the Anvāhāryapacana is its Yajur verse, the mid-region its Devevyam; the Āhavanīya is its Sāma verse, the world of heaven its destination, hence they declare Agni as the highest.

sloka: agnihotra~ sāyaṃ prātargṛhāṇāṃ niṣkṛtiḥ sviṣṭa~ suhutaṃ yajñakratūnāṃ prāyaṇa~ suvargasya lokasya jyotistasmādagnihotra~ paramaṃ vadanti ||
translation: The evening and morning oblations through Agnihotra are the purification of homes, the auspicious offering in yajnakratu, and the light leading to the attainment of the heavenly world. Therefore, they declare Agnihotra to be the supreme.

sloka: vasanti prāṇino yatra |
translation: "Where living beings dwell, it is spring" or "The dwelling place of living beings is spring."

sloka: tataḥ tu irāvatīm nāma jajñe bhadramadā sutām | tasyāḥ tu airāvataḥ putro lokanātho mahāgajaḥ ||
translation: Then was born Irāvatī, named Bhadramadā's daughter. Her son was Airāvata, the great elephant and lord of the worlds.

sloka: cāturvarṇyaṃ mayā sṛṣṭaṃ guṇakarmavibhāgaśaḥ | tasya kartāramapi māṃ viddhyakartāramavyayam ||
translation: The four-class division was created by me, based on qualities and actions. Know me too as the non-transitory creator of that system based on quality and action.

sloka: eṣāmutpattyādiryathā yadā bhagavān puruṣarūpeṇa sṛṣṭiṃ kṛtavān tadāsyaśarīrāt catvāro varṇā utpannāḥ mukhato brāhmaṇāḥ bāhutaḥ kṣatriyāḥ ūruto vaiśyāḥ pādataḥ śūdrā jātāḥ
translation: At the time when the Lord assumed the form of a Purusha and created, then from his body emerged four varnas (social classes) - Brahmins from the mouth, Kshatriyas in large numbers from the arms, Vaishyas from the thighs, and Shudras from the feet.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The brahmin was born from his mouth, the ruler from his arms, the vaishya from his thighs, and the shudra from his feet.

sloka: āśramaḥ śāstrokta dharmmaviśeṣaḥ| āśrāmyanti svaṃ svaṃ tapaścarantyatra | sa caturvidhaḥ | brahmacaryyaṃ gārhasthyaṃ vānaprasthyaṃ sannyāsaḥ | iti smṛtiḥ || brahmacārī | gṛhī | vānaprasthaḥ | bhikṣuḥ | ityamaraḥ ||
translation: The āśrama, as instructed by the śāstra, is a specific aspect of dharma. In this āśrama, individuals pursue their own tapas. It is fourfold, consisting of brahmacarya, gārhastya, vānaprastha, and sannyāsa. This is remembered as: the brahmacārī, gṛhī, vānaprastha, and bhikṣu.

sloka: trayo dharmaskandhā yajño'dhyayanaṃ dānamiti prathamastapa eva dvitīyo brahmacāryācāryakulavāsī tṛtīyo'tyantamātmānamācāryakule'vasādayansarva ete puṇyalokā bhavanti brahmasa~stho'mṛtatvameti || ||
translation: The three branches of dharma are sacrifice , study , and charity . Those who follow the first, living in the teacher's household as a student, the second, observing celibacy and serving the teacher's family, and the third, dedicating oneself completely to self-study and realization while residing in the teacher's household, all these attain auspicious worlds and ultimately, become one with Brahman, achieving immortality.

sloka: yathā vāyuṃ samāśritya vartante sarvajantavaḥ | tathā gṛhasthaṃ āśritya vartante sarva āśramāḥ | | | | yasmāttrayo'pyāśramiṇo jñānenānnena cānvaham | gṛhasthenaiva dhāryante tasmājjyeṣṭhāśramo gṛhī | | | |
translation: Just as all creatures depend on the wind and function accordingly, similarly all ashrams (stages of life) function relying on the householder. Indeed, due to knowledge alone, the three other ashrams are supported by the householder; therefore, the householder's stage is considered the highest.

sloka: ṛgvedaṃ bhagavo'dhyemi yajurveda~ sāmavedamātharvaṇaṃ caturthamitihāsapurāṇaṃ pañcamaṃ vedānāṃ vedaṃ pitrya~ rāśiṃ daivaṃ nidhiṃ vākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyāṃ brahmavidyāṃ bhūtavidyāṃ kṣatravidyāṃ nakṣatravidyāṃ sarpadevajñavidyāmetadbhagavo'dhyemi
translation: I study the Rigveda, truly; I endeavor to learn the Yajurveda and Samaveda too, as well as the Atharvanangirasa, considered the fourth Veda. The fifth is the collection of historical accounts, hymns, and philosophies known as the Itihasapurana. I seek to understand the knowledge of the Gods, the Brahman, the creatures, the warrior, the stars, and the science of serpent-demons. This, I study.

sloka: so'haṃ bhagavo mantravidevāsmi nā''tmavicchuta~hyeva me bhagavoddṛśebhyastarati śokamātmaviditi so'haṃ bhagavaḥ śocāmi taṃ mā bhagavā ñchokasya parāṃ tārayatviti ta~hovāca yadvai kiṃcaitadadhyagīṣṭhānāmaivaitat
translation:
I am that mantra-knowing being, sovereign Lord; it will never leave me, this knowledge of the self that wards off grief. Therefore I am, sovereign Lord, full of sorrow. May you not add to this grief of mine, but instead liberate him from the great ocean of sorrow.
He then said: "Indeed, this is the highest name."

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name of the first is Rigveda, Yajurveda the second, the third SamaVEDA, and Atharvan the fourth; the fifth is Itihāsa-Purāṇa, known as the knowledge of Pitrs, the vast wealth, the lore of words, divine vidyā, brahma vidyā, knowledge of beings, kshatra vidyā, knowledge of stars, and serpent-deva jñana. Thus are named these names to be meditated upon.

sloka: yadā vai vijānātyatha satyaṃ vadati nāvijānansatyaṃ vadati vijānanneva satyaṃ vadati vijñānaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti vijñānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one truly understands, they speak the truth. If they do not understand, they still may speak the truth unknowingly. But, knowing or unknowing, speaking the truth is to be understood (to be sought after). Thus, the Lord said, "Understand this to be understood."

sloka: yadā vai manute'tha vijānāti nāmatvā vijānāti matvaiva vijānāti matistveva vijijñāsitavyeti matiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: "When one ponders and understands 'this is name,' but does not understand beyond that; only knows what is thought, yet should investigate further - thus should the understanding be sought, Bhagavan."

sloka: yadā vai śraddadhātyatha manute nāśraddadhanmanute śraddadheva manute śraddhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti śraddhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one fully dedicates themself to faith, as they think, so they become. They should investigate this matter of faith: "What is this faith that the Blessed One inquires about?"

sloka: yadā vai nistiṣṭhatyatha śraddadhāti nānistiṣṭhacchraddadhāti nistiṣṭhanneva śraddadhāti niṣṭhātveva vijijñāsitavyeti niṣṭhāṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When one fully establishes themselves, then they truly develop faith, not when they are unestablished. One should inquire into 'firmness' (niṣṭhā), O Lord, for this is what ought to be understood as 'firmness'.

sloka: yadā vai karotyatha nistiṣṭhati nākṛtvā nistiṣṭhati kṛtvaiva nistiṣṭhati kṛtistveva vijijñāsitavyeti kṛtiṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: "When one acts or settles without having acted, or settles after having acting, or even when settled in action itself, all these should be examined, says the Lord."

sloka: yadā vai sukhaṃ labhate'tha karoti nāsukhaṃ labdhvā karoti sukhameva labdhvā karoti sukhaṃ tveva vijijñāsitavyamiti sukhaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: When happiness is obtained, one should do (only) happy actions, not (do) unhappy ones; having obtained happiness, one should do happy actions only. This should be specially understood as 'happiness', the Blessed One said, referring to happiness.

sloka: vedam evābhyasennityaṃ yathākām atandritaḥ | taṃ hyasyāhuḥ paraṃ dharmam upadharmo'nya ucyate
translation: "One should regularly study the Vedas with enthusiasm, as one desires. What is otherwise than this is called adharmah (unrighteousness)."

sloka: vayasaḥ karmaṇo'rthasya śrutasyābhijanasya ca | veṣavāgbuddhisārūpyaṃ ācaranvicarediha śrutismṛtyuditaṃ samyaṅnibaddhaṃ sveṣu karmasu | dharmamūlaṃ niṣeveta sadācāraṃ atandritaḥ ācārāllabhate hyāyurācārādīpsitāḥ prajāḥ | ācārāddhanaṃ akṣayyaṃ ācāro hantyalakṣaṇam
translation: Of hearing , social class , and the purpose of actions, one should properly abide, regulated by the rule of conduct in his own duties , illuminated by scripture and tradition. One should always cultivate Dharma, which is the root of proper conduct , unwaveringly. Proper conduct leads to longevity and is desirable for offspring . Wealth arises from proper conduct and it is the marker of one who should be killed .

sloka: kaṇādena tu saṃproktaṃ śāstraṃ vaiśeṣikaṃ mahat | gautamena tathā nyāyaṃ sāṃkhyaṃ tu kapilena vai ||
translation: The Vaiseshika shastra was mentioned by Kanada, while Gautama expounded on Nyaya; Samkhya was taught by Kapila.

sloka: saḥ eṣaḥ saptabhiḥ puruṣairnipaṉna ekaḥ puruṣaḥ prajāpatiḥ virāṭ abhūt evaṃ liṅgaśarīrābhimānihiraṇyagarbhakartṛkā virāḍutpattiruktā tasya virājo'gnirūpatāmāha sa yaḥ puruṣaḥ iti sa prajāpatiḥ eva ayaṃ cīyamānaḥ agniḥ ityarthaḥ kāṇḍikā atha yo garbho'ntarāsīt so'gnirasṛjyata sa yadasya sarvasyāgramasṛjyata tasmādagniḥ agnirhavai tamagnirityācakṣate paro'kṣam paro'kṣakāmā hi devāḥ kāṇḍikā
translation:
This very Purusha, when created by seven Purushas, is one. He became Prajapati and Virat. Thus, the formation of his linga-sharira (subtle body) was accomplished, along with the Hiranyagarbha (Cosmic Egg) and Kartrika (creative power). This is how the manifestation of Virat took place.
Then, Agni (fire) was assigned its form (as a representation of the Purusha). The one who is called Purusha is indeed Prajapati. Similarly, this ongoing process of creation is referred to as 'Agni'. The seers and those who seek knowledge call it by various names like 'Paroksha' and 'Parokshakama'. As per Kaandika (a Hindu scripture), the fire that was born from the Garbha (womb) within, is Agni. And the one who creates everything in its entirety is also referred to as Agni.

sloka: medhāyai manase'gnaye svāheti medhayā vai manasābhigacchati yajeyeti tadasyetadamubhayamātmanyeva yanmedhā ca manaśca te asminnete ubhe devate ātmanyādhīte
translation: For intellect, "Svaha" (is offered) in the mind-fire; with intellect, indeed, one reaches the mind. One should sacrifice to it. This (sacrifice) is for both in the self alone, whatever is intellect and mind. In this Self, both of them, the intellect and the mind, should be devoted.

sloka: sa tvamagniṃ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tvaṃ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You indeed know that heavenly fire, O Death; please tell this to me who has faith. The abodes of heaven bestow immortality; I choose this as my second boon.

sloka: atha hāgnaya: samūdire tapto brahmacārī kuśalaṃ na: paryacārīddhantāsmai prabravāmeti tasmai hocu: || ||
translation: "Then, to Agneya, who had been purified by austerities and was engaged in celibacy, they said, 'Expert in rituals, well done! We approve.'"

sloka: atha hainaṃ gārhapatyo'nu śaśāsa pṛthivyagnirannamāditya iti ya | eṣa āditye puruṣo dṛśyate so'hamasmi sa evāhamasmīti || ||
translation: "Then the gārhapatya fire addressed him, 'This is the earth-offering, Aditya (the sun).' The person seen in the sun, that is me. I am indeed that."

sloka: yadā lelāyate hṛārci: samiddhe havyavāhane tadājyabhāgāvantareṇāhutī: pratipādayet
translation: When the fire within the heart flickers , then an offering , along with the portion of oblation , should be presented in the other fire .

sloka: kālī karālī ca manojavā ca sulohitā yā ca sudhūmravarṇā sphuliṅginīṃ viśvarucī ca devī lelāyamānā iti sapta jihvā:
translation: The seven tongues are Kali, Karali, Manojava, Sulohita, Sudhumravarna, Sphulingini, and Visvaruci.

sloka: śākalyaseya śataṃ śiṣyā naiṣṭhikabrahmacāriṇaḥ pañca teṣāṃ gṛhasthāste dharmaniṣṭhāśca kuṭumbinaḥ śiśiro vāṣkalo sāṃkhyo vātsyaścaivāśvalāyanaḥ pañcaite śākalāḥ śiṣyāḥ śākhābhedapravarttakāḥ
translation: The disciple of Shakalyaseya, a hundred in number, are lifelong brahmacharis. Of them, five become grihasthas (householders) and dharmanishtas (steadfast in righteousness), along with their families. Shishira, Vaskala, Sankhyo, Vatsya, and Ashvalayana - these five are the disciples of Shakalyaseya who initiate new branches (of knowledge/sect).

sloka: ijyate'neneti yajuḥ
translation: "is worshipped as 'nen'," or more idiomatically in English, "goes by the name 'nen' in the ritual" (where 'nen' is the name of the deity or thing being worshipped). The Yajurveda contains mantras that are used in various rituals and ceremonies.

sloka: aniyatākṣarāvasāno yajuḥ ||
translation: Of unfixed meter, the Yajus (sacrifice) ||

sloka: gadyātmako yajuḥ
translation:
The Yajur Veda is in prose form.

(Note: 'Gadyatmaka' means 'consisting of prose' and 'Yajuh' refers to the Yajur Veda, one of the four Vedas in Hinduism, which is primarily composed in prose.)

sloka: ādityānīmāni śuklāni yajūṃṣi vājasaneyena yājñavalkyenākhyāyante
translation: These are the bright Aditya Yajus hymns known as Vajasaneyi, named by Yajnavalkya.

sloka: sā cāmaśceti tatsāmnaḥ sāmatvam |
translation: She achieves equality with him, that even-mindedness.

sloka: vedānāṃ sāmavedosmi |
translation: I am the Rigveda of the Vedas.

sloka: ‘karmacodanā brāhmaṇāni
translation:
'Performed by brahminas as a religious duty' or 'Ceremonies conducted by brahmanas'
(Note: The word 'karmacodana' is derived from the root words 'karma' (action, work) and 'codana' (inciting, encouraging). Here, it refers to the ceremonies or rituals performed by brahminas as part of their religious duties.)

sloka: araṇye'dhīyūrān
translation: "noble heroes in the wilderness"

sloka: vaiśvānaraḥ praviśati atithirbrāhmaṇo gṛhān | tasyaitā~ śāntiṃ kurvanti hara vaivasvatodakam || ||
translation: The all-pervading fire (Agni) enters, like a guest, the brahmin's house; they make his hunger (fire's) peaceful (satisfied) by giving him oblations of rice or grains.

sloka: āśāpratīkṣe saṅgata~ sūnṛtāṃ ca iṣṭāpūrte putrapaśū~śca sarvān | etadvṛṅkte puruṣasyālpamedhaso yasyānaśnanvasati brāhmaṇo gṛhe || ||
translation: The man of meager intelligence, who with unresting hope and expectation, welcomes guests, is nourished in a Brahmin's house along with all his sons and animals.

sloka: ki~svidyamasya kartavyaṃ yanmayā'dya kariṣyati || ||
translation: What needs to be done immediately by me?

sloka: śāntasaṅkalpaḥ sumanā yathā syādvītamanyurgautamo mābhimṛtyo | tvatprasṛṣṭaṃ mā'bhivadetpratīta etat trayāṇāṃ prathama varaṃ vṛṇe || ||
translation: May I always be of a peaceful disposition, happy and free from hatred, just like the river Gautami, which is revered by many. This, I choose as the foremost among the three boons you have the power to grant.

sloka: yathā purastādbhavitā pratīta auddālakirāruṇirmatprasṛṣṭaḥ | sukha~ rātrīḥ śayitā vītamanyuḥ tvāṃ dadṛśivānmṛtyumukhāt pramuktam || ||
translation: Like a firmly established post, noticed at dawn, reddish-tinged and surrounded by morning mist, you were seen, lying on the bed, free from anger during the pleasant nights, as if released from the jaws of death.

sloka: svarge loke na bhayaṃ kiñcanāsti na tatra tvaṃ na jarayā bibheti | ubhe tīrtvā aśanāyāpipāse śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: In heaven there is no fear at all, nor should you fear there; not (do you fear) old age; having crossed over both (fear of) hunger and thirst, and grief, one delights in the heavenly world.

sloka: sa tvamagni~ svargyamadhyeṣi mṛtyo prabrūhi tva~ śraddadhānāya mahyam | svargalokā amṛtatvaṃ bhajanta etad dvitīyena vṛṇe vareṇa || ||
translation: You indeed are the fire, situated in the heavenly realm; O Death, reveal to me, who is full of faith. May I enjoy immortality in the world of heaven; I choose this second boon.

sloka: prate bravīmi tadu me nibodha svargyamagniṃ naciketaḥ prajānan | anantalokāptimatho pratiṣṭhāṃ viddhi tvametaṃ nihitaṃ guhāyām || ||
translation: I tell you, Naciketa, understand thatSvargyagni, the fire of heaven; learn from me about its established foundation,the unending succession of lokas (worlds) that constitute its pinnacle, hidden in a mystery.

sloka: lokādimagniṃ tamuvāca tasmai yā iṣṭakā yāvatīrvā yathā vā | sa cāpi tatpratyavadadyathoktaṃ athāsya mṛtyuḥ punarevāha tuṣṭaḥ || ||
translation: The one who blazes like a fire at the beginning of the world spoke to him, fulfilling his desired offering, in whatever way it was. He too responded to what was said, and thus death became pleased with him again.

sloka: tamabravītprīyamāṇo mahātmā varaṃ tavehādya dadāmi bhūyaḥ | tavaiva nāmnā bhavitāyamagniḥ sṛṅkāṃ cemāmanekarūpāṃ gṛhāṇa || ||
translation: "Being pleased, the great-souled one said: I grant you an additional boon. Let this fire become yours, named after you, taking on this singular form."

sloka: yeyaṃ prete vicikitsā manuṣye astītyeke nāyamastīti caike | etadvidyāmanuśiṣṭastvayā'haṃ varāṇāmeṣa varastṛtīyaḥ || ||
translation: The doubt that exists in people about whether there is a soul after death, some say it does, others say it doesn't. This very knowledge you should master; I am telling you, it is the third of the desirable things.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ purā na hi suvijñeyamaṇureṣa dharmaḥ | anyaṃ varaṃ naciketo vṛṇīṣva mā moparotsīrati mā sṛjainam || ||
translation: "This duty has been pondered upon even by the gods in ancient times, for it is not easily understood. Therefore, Naciketa, choose another boon; do not hesitate, do not refuse."

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ kila tvaṃ ca mṛtyo yanna sujñeyamāttha | vaktā cāsya tvādṛganyo na labhyo nānyo varastulya etasya kaścit || ||
translation: "Even gods are uncertain about you, death, as you are not easily understood. No one like you, comparable to a rare treasure, can be found as your substitute."

sloka: yasminnidaṃ vicikitsanti mṛtyo yatsāmparāye mahati brūhi nastat | yo'yaṃ varo gūḍhamanupraviṣṭo nānyaṃ tasmānnaciketā vṛṇīte || ||
translation: In whom do they doubt about this (transmigration of the soul) and about the great approaching death, tell me that is indeed hidden (unmanifested) wealth; therefore, Acquitaine should not choose any other but this.

sloka: naiva vācā na manasā prāptuṃ śakyo na cakṣuṣā | astīti bruvato'nyatra kathaṃ tadupalabhyate || ||
translation: "It cannot be grasped by speech, mind or sight. How then can it be apprehended if someone says 'it is not'?"

sloka: astītyevopalabdhavyastattvabhāvena cobhayoḥ | astītyevopalabdhasya tattvabhāvaḥ prasīdati || ||
translation: The true nature of both is realized when found to be truly present. The true nature of what is indeed found shines forth.

sloka: yadā sarve pramucyante kāmā ye'sya hṛdi śritāḥ | atha martyo'mṛto bhavatyatra brahma samaśnute || ||
translation: When all desires that are dwelling in the heart fully depart, then the mortal becomes immortal, such is the consummation of Brahman.

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: "This alone is the imperishable Brahman, this alone is the supreme. Knowing this, one's desire is fulfilled."

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye saṃniviṣṭaḥ | taṃ svāccharīrātpravṛhenmuñjādiveṣīkāṃ dhairyeṇa | taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtaṃ taṃ vidyācchukramamṛtamiti || ||
translation: The self within all beings, as small as a thumb, always resides in their hearts. With courage, one should extract it from one's own body, that imperishable, supremely subtle nectar; that indeed is the imperishable, supremely subtle nectar.

sloka: triṇāciketastribhiretya sandhiṃ trikarmakṛttarati janmamṛtyū | brahmajajñaṃ devamīḍyaṃ viditvā nicāyya mā~ śāntimatyantameti || ||
translation: Three-part-fire, having joined the three (states of) being-nonbeing-becoming, transcends rebirth; knowing the divinity, the wondrous Brahma-knower, having approached, one does not attain absolute peace without.

sloka: triṇāciketastrayametadviditvā ya evaṃ vidvā~ ścinute nāciketam | sa mṛtyupāśānpurataḥ praṇodya śokātigo modate svargaloke || ||
translation: Understanding the three-fold fire herein, the one who knows thus, delighting in having transcended death's grasp, rejoices in the heavenly world.

sloka: pratigrahasamartho'pi prasaṅgaṃ tatra varjayet | pratigraheṇa hyasyāśu brāhmaṃ tejaḥ praśāmyati naitādṛśaḥ paro dharmo nṛṇāṃ saddharmamicchatām nyāso daṇḍasya bhūteṣu manovākkāyajasya yaḥ
translation: Capable of accepting gifts or not, one should avoid that gathering; because, through acceptance, his Brahmanical power/energy is pacified. Such is not the conduct of those who follow righteousness and establish the rod (of punishment) upon themselves among beings, in relation to mental, verbal, and physical actions.

sloka: yathā candraśca rohiṇyāmurmilāyāṃ dhaneśvaraḥ|| yatra rājā vaivasvato yatrāvarodhanaṃ divaḥ yatrāmūryahvatīrāpastatra māmamṛtaṃ kṛdhīndrāyendo pari srava
translation: Like the moon (candra) merging with Rohini (one of the 27 asterisms in Indian astronomy), O Lord of wealth (Dhanesvara), where the king Vaivasvata (sun god) sets, where the division between day and night occurs, where the river Amrvati flows, there make me immortal, Indra.

sloka: tisro dyāvaḥ savitura dvā upasthāṃ ekā yamasya bhuvane virāṣāṭa āṇiṃ na rathyamamṛtādhi tasthuriha bravītu ya u tacciketat
translation: "Of the three heavenly realms of Savitar, two have come up for ascension, only one remains in this world as the unchanging support, let not the imperishable speak of this to one who does not understand."

sloka: naciketamupākhyānaṃ mṛtyuproktaṃ sanātanam
translation: The eternal tale of Naciketa, as told by Death.

sloka: aṅguṣṭhamātraḥ puruṣo'ntarātmā sadā janānāṃ hṛdaye sanniviṣṭaḥ
translation: The self within all beings, of the size of a thumb, always dwells in the heart of humans.

sloka: dharati lokān dhriyate puṇyātmabhiriti vā |
translation: Supports (or holds) the worlds, is sustained by meritorious soul-force.

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmin is to be known by birth, designated as dvija by rituals, attains vipra status through learning, and characterized by scriptural knowledge and proper conduct; this forms the basis for distinguishing expiatory actions.

sloka: ākāśādvāyuḥ | vāyoragniḥ | agnerāpaḥ | adbhyaḥ pṛthivī ||| ||
translation: From ether arises air, from air fire, from fire water, and from water earth.

sloka: dyaurme pitā janitā nābhiratra bandhurme mātā pṛthivī mahīyam |||
translation: The sky is my father, the earth is my mother, and the wide expanses are my friend.

sloka: mātā bhūmiḥ putro'haṃ pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation: I am the son of earth, the earth is my mother.

sloka: yatte bhūme vikhanāmi kṣipraṃ tadapi rohatu | mā te marma vimṛgvari mā te hṛdayamarpipam ||
translation: Whatever I dig up from the earth, may it quickly grow back. May my actions not harm your vital parts, nor let my heart become insensitive.

sloka: upasthāste anamīvā ayakṣmā asmabhyaṃ santu pṛthivi prasūtāḥ | dīrghaṃ na āyuḥ pratibudhyamānā vayaṃ tubhyaṃ balihṛtaḥ syāma ||
translation: Let fertile Earth stand near us, free from pestilence and cough. May we long live, becoming stronger, as we awaken to you (O two Auspicious Ones).

sloka: indro yātūnāmabhavatparāśaro havirmathīnāmabhyā vivāsatām abhīdu śakraḥ paraśuryathā vanaṃ pātreva bhindantsata eti rakṣasaḥ
translation: Indra is the most powerful among the Yatudhanas, and Parashara among those offering sacrifices; like a sharp sword slicing through a tender leaf, the Rakshasa (demon) Parashu quickly departs after striking.

sloka: nahi nu yādadhīmasīndraṃ ko vīryā paraḥ tasminnṛmṇamuta kratuṃ devā ojāṃsi saṃ dadhurarcannanu svarājyam
translation: Not even Indra, the king of gods, has such superior power and energy. The gods together deposited their energies and power as an offering in him, making him the rightful ruler.

sloka: indrasyāṅagirasāṃ ceṣṭau vidat saramā tanayāya dhāsim bṛhaspatirbhinadadriṃ vidad gāḥ samusriyābhirvāvaśanta naraḥ evaṃ purā svānapi sodarān sa garbhasthitānujjarituṃ bhayārtaḥ| bibheda vajreṇa tataḥ sa gotrabhit khyāto
translation: The exertion of Indra and the Angirases was manifest, as Saraswati hastily approached her son; Brihaspati split open the Adri mountain, such was the sound of cows lowing. Thus, in the past, even his own sisters did not hesitate to abort the embryo out of fear. Then, he was famously known as the one whose womb was split with thunder.

sloka: devā ūcurindro vai devānāmojiṣṭho baliṣṭhaḥ sahiṣṭhaḥ sattamaḥ pārayiṣṇutamastaṃ
translation: "The gods said, 'Indra is the most loved, the strongest, the most revered, and the best of the seekers.'"

sloka: pūrvaṃ kṛtayuge tāta parvatāḥ pakṣiṇo'bhavan te hi jagmurdiśaḥ sarvā garuḍānilaveginaḥ
translation: In the previous age of Krita, my dear, mountains became birds and all of them flew in various directions with the speed of Garuda.

sloka: tatasteṣu prayāteṣu devasaṃghaḥ saharṣibhiḥ bhūtāni ca bhayaṃ jagmusteṣāṃ patanaśaṅkayā
translation: On the approach of those (celestial cars), the assembly of gods, along with the great seers, became afraid due to the fear of falling (down).

sloka: tataḥ kruddhaḥ sahasrākṣaḥ parvatānāṃ śatakratuḥ pakṣān ciccheda vajreṇa tatra tatra sahasraśaḥ
translation: Then, angry, the thousand-eyed Indra , wielding his thunderbolt , split apart the peaks of the mountains there and there by the hundreds .

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam |
translation: One should not be negligent towards duties towards gods and ancestors.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: Worship of the lord during special occasions or festivals.

sloka: mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava |
translation: Be a revered mother, be a revered father, be a revered teacher, be a revered guest.

sloka: rājartviksnātakagurūnpriyaśvaśuramātulān | arhayenmadhuparkeṇa parisaṃvatsarātpunaḥ | | | | saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: Honoring the father-in-law, mother-in-law, and other relatives who are like a guru, one should offer them gifts on occasions such as madhuparks (rituals involving honey) and after a year has passed. One should give them a respectful seat and water for washing their feet. Additionally, one should offer food according to one's ability, following proper procedures.

sloka: sattvaṃ rajastama iti guṇāḥ prakṛtisaṃbhavāḥ | nibadhnanti mahābāho dehe dehinamavyayam ||
translation: The qualities born of Prakrti, sattva, rajas, and tamas bind the imperishable soul in the body, O mighty-armed one.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: The sattva (purity, knowledge) prevails in happiness, rajas (passion, activity) in actions, O Bharata; but, covered by ignorance, tamas (inertia, delusion) prevails in confusion.

sloka: rajastamaścābhibhūya sattvaṃ bhavati bhārata | rajaḥ sattvaṃ tamaścaiva tamaḥ sattvaṃ rajastathā ||
translation: By overcoming rajas and tamas, sattva prevails, O Bharata. Similarly, sattva and tamas overcome rajas, and tamas is dominated by sattva and rajas.

sloka: māṃ ca yo'vyabhicāreṇa bhaktiyogena sevate | sa guṇānsamatītyaitānbrahmabhūyāya kalpate || brahmaṇo hi pratiṣṭhāhamamṛtasyāvyayasya ca | śāśvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaikāntikasya ca ||
translation: One who serves me with devotional dedication, unaffected by separation from me, is fit for becoming Brahman, transcending these gunas (constituent qualities of prakriti). For I am the foundation of Brahman, immortality, imperishability, eternal righteousness, and ultimate happiness.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣeyaḥ yonāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavatyamataṃ matamavijñāātaṃ vijñātamiti kathaṃ nu bhagavaḥ sa ādeśo bhavatīti
translation: "How can an undetermined rule apply to that which is unseen, heard only through rumor, and unknown? How can this be your command, O Bhagavan?"

sloka: hovācānanuśiṣya vāva kila mā bhagavānabravīdanutvā'śiṣamiti
translation: "The teacher, having taught the lesson, then said, 'Surely, do not let this instruction go unheeded.'"

sloka: pañca mā rājanyabandhuḥ praśrnāprākṣītteṣāṃ naikaṃ ca nāśakaṃ vivaktumiti
translation: Five royal allies, on being asked repeatedly by those assembled, none of them could clearly express a view or make a decision.

sloka: sa hovāca yathā mā tvaṃ tadaitānavado yathā'hameṣāṃ naikaṃ ca na veda yadyahamimānavediṣyaṃ kathaṃ te nāvakṣyāmiti
translation: He said, "How can I inform you of something that I myself don't know? Just as I am not familiar with all of their (these) strengths and weaknesses, how then would I not be unable to describe it to you?"

sloka: mānuṣasya bhagavangautama vittasya varaṃ vṛṇīthā iti
translation: "O Bhagavan Shautama, choose the best portion of human wealth."

sloka: sa hovāca tavaiva rājanmānuṣaṃ vittaṃ yāmeva kumārasyānte vācamabhāṣathāstāmeva me brūhiti sa ha kṛcchrī babhūva
translation: He (the sage Asita) said to you, O king: "Reveal the human wealth (of spiritual knowledge) to the young prince at the end of his life, just as it was told to me." He became grief-stricken.

sloka: sūryaḥ dyusthānaḥ | vāyuḥ vā indraḥ vā antarikṣasthānaḥ | agniḥ pṛthivīsthānaḥ |
translation: Sun is in the heaven, wind is in the mid-region, fire is on the earth, or alternatively, Sun is in his position (in the sky), wind is in its position (in the mid-region), fire is in its position (on the earth).

sloka: aṅgayanti agyraṃ janma prāpayanti itivyutpattyā aṅgati ūrddhvaṃ gacchati iti agi gatau ||
translation: "Bearing in the body they originate , lifting upwards they go - such is the nature of growth ."

sloka: sa vā eṣo'gre devatānāmajāyatā tasmādagrirnāmāgrirha vai nāmaitadyadagnirityāhuḥ sa u jātaḥ pūrvaḥ prayāya tadvaivāsya dvitīyamagritvaṃ pūrvaṃhi yantamāhuragra etīti ||
translation: Indeed, this first-born of the gods, named 'Agni,' was born beforehand. Therefore, the designation 'agri' (first) is given, and 'grha' (house), truly meaning the place where Agni is situated first. When Agni is born anew, they say that 'agra' (firewood) has come to be; thus, 'agra' indicates both the earlier and the later emergence of fire.

sloka: prajāpatirha vā idamagra eka evāsa | sa aikṣata kathaṃ nu prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata so'gnimeva mukhājjanayāṃcakre tadyadenaṃ mukhādajanayata tasmādannādo'gniḥ
translation: Prajapati, initially alone, considered, "how should I procreate?" After practicing austerities, he made (procreation) similar to the mouth-born fire. Therefore, the mouth is considered the origin of fire.

sloka: agnimūrdhā cakṣuṣī candrasūryau diśa: śrotre vāgvivṛtāśca vedā: vāyu: prāṇo hṛdayaṃ viśvamasya padbhayāṃ pṛthivī hyeṣa sarvabhūtāntarātmā sthālīsthānaṃ gato'śvatthaṃ śamīgarbhaṃ vilakṣya saḥ | tena dve araṇī kṛtvā urvaśīlokakāmyayā || ||
translation: Lighting Agni (fire) on top, the eyes are for Sun and Moon, directions for the ears, speech for the Vedas, air for breath, heart is the center of universe, earth is its foundation, it is the inner self of all beings, established in the Ashwattha tree (fig tree), recognized as born from a Shamlee seed. Having done this, two pieces of firewood are created with the desire of getting Urvasi (a celestial nymph).

sloka: urvaśīṃ mantrato dhyāyan adharāraṇimuttarām | ātmānaṃ ubhayormadhye yattat prajananaṃ prabhuḥ || ||
translation:
Meditating on Urvaśi, lifting her from the lower regions,
The Lord discerns his self in both aspects.

sloka: tasya nirmanthanāt jāto jātavedā vibhāvasuḥ | trayyā sa vidyayā rājñā putratve kalpitastrivṛt || ||
translation:
Born from his creation, the fire god Jātavedas,
Manifested through the threefold knowledge as the king's offspring.

sloka: jātavedāḥ kasmāt | jātavit yaḥ vā jātaprajñānaḥ | jātāni veda | tasya eṣā bhavati | jāte jāte vidyate iti vā | jātadhanaḥ |
translation: "O Jātavedā (fire god), why are you called Jātavedā, or Jātavit, or Jātprajñāna? You know the born (jātāni). This is your appellation due to your knowing the newly born (jāte jāte) again and again."

sloka: tantrādhikaraṇābhyupagamasaṃsthitiḥ siddhāntaḥ || {siddhāntalakṣaṇam}
translation: The established understanding is the acceptance of the authority in matters related to tantra. (siddhantalaksanam)

sloka: dvividho hi vedokto dharmaḥ pravṛttilakṣaṇo nivṛttilakṣaṇaśca jagataḥ stithikāraṇam prāṇināṃ sākṣādabhyudayaniḥśreyasaheturya
translation: The term dharma, as mentioned in the Vedas, has two aspects: it is indicated by pravrtti (principled action leading to worldly life) and nivrtti (withdrawal or renunciation leading to spiritual liberation). It plays a direct role in establishing and maintaining the well-being and ultimate success of living beings.

sloka: hiṃsraṃ dravyamayaṃ kāmyamagnihotrādyaśāntidam darśaśca pūrṇamāsaśca cāturmāsyaṃ paśuḥ sutaḥ etadiṣṭaṃ pravṛttākhyaṃ hutaṃ prahutameva ca pūrtaṃ surālayārāma kūpā jīvyādilakṣaṇam
translation: The harmful, desire-motivated oblation, consisting of materials, which is peaceful for Agnihotra and other rituals, along with the new and full moon sacrifices, and the animal sacrifice in the four-month ritual; this has been established as the act called Huta and Prahuta, and is recognized as the sustenance of the gods' dwelling places, parks, wells, etc.

sloka: naṣṭo mohaḥ smṛtirlabdhā tvatprasādānmayācyuta | sthito'smi gatasandehaḥ kariṣye vacanaṃ tava || ||
translation: "My illusion is destroyed, and remembrance has been obtained through your grace, O Immutable One. I stand firm with doubts dispelled; I will carry out your command."

sloka: saṃnyāsaḥ karmayogaśca niḥśreyasakarāvubhau | tayostu karmasaṃnyāsātkarmayogo viśiṣyate || ||
translation: Renunciation of actions and action-yoga, both lead to liberation; however, of the two, action-yoga is superior because of the complete renunciation of actions it involves.

sloka: tapasvibhyo'dhiko yogī jñānibhyo'pi mato'dhikaḥ | karmibhyaścādhiko yogī tasmādyogī bhavārjuna || ||
translation: A yogi is superior to ascetics, also considered superior to those accomplished in knowledge, and superior to even the doers of actions. Therefore, become a yogi, Arjuna.

sloka: puruṣaḥ sa paraḥ pārtha bhaktyā labhyastvananyayā | yasyāntaḥsthāni bhūtāni yena sarvamidaṃ tatam || ||
translation: The Supreme Purusha, O Partha, is attainable through devotion and none other way. He within whom all beings dwell and who dwells in all this.

sloka: udārāḥ sarva evaite jñānī tvātmaiva me matam | āsthitaḥ sa hi yuktātmā māmevānuttamāṃ gatim || ||
translation: All of them are generous, but only the knower of the self is my opinion. One who is established in the true self, indeed, reaches the supreme goal.

sloka: tasmādasaktaḥ satataṃ kāryaṃ karma samācara | asakto hyācarankarma paramāpnoti pūruṣaḥ || ||
translation: Therefore, always perform your duty with attachment, but without attachment seek to do your duty; for by doing duties without attachment, a person attains the highest good.

sloka: brahmaṇyādhāya karmāṇi saṅgaṃ tyaktvā karoti yaḥ | lipyate na sa pāpena padmapatramivāmbhasā || ||
translation: One who, dedicating actions to Brahman, discards attachment, is not tainted by sin, just like a lotus leaf in water.

sloka: sarvopaniṣado gāvo dogdhā gopālanandanaḥ | pārtho vatsaḥ sudhīrbhoktā dugdhaṃ gītāmṛtaṃ mahat ||
translation: All the Upanishads are cows, their milk is the transcendental knowledge; the milker is the discerning person, the calf is the worthy receiver; the milk is the holy Bhagavad Gita, the great nectar.

sloka: kasminnu bhagavo vijñāte sarvamidaṃ vijñātaṃ bhavatīti || ||
translation: "On knowing which (thing) indeed, everything becomes known," or "Once you know that, all this becomes known."

sloka: mamaivāṃśo jīvaloke jīvabhūtaḥ sanātanaḥ| manaḥṣaṣṭhānīndriyāṇi prakṛtisthāni karṣati||||
translation: The living being in this world, which is a part of me, is eternal; the five organs of perception and the mind are forced to act by the inherent nature (prakriti).

sloka: virāṭsutāḥ somasadaḥ sādhyānāṃ pitaraḥ smṛtāḥ | agniṣvāttāśca devānāṃ mārīcā lokaviśrutāḥ daityadānavayakṣāṇāṃ gandharvoragarakṣasām | suparṇakinnarāṇāṃ ca smṛtā barhiṣado'trijāḥ
translation: The sons of Virat are remembered as Somasada, the fathers of the Sadhyas. AgniSvatta and the famous Marici are known as the forefathers of the gods. The Barhisad and Atri are considered as the progenitors of the Suparna, Kinnara, and other celestial beings. The Gandharva, Rakshasa, Daitya, and Danava are descended from them.

sloka: somapā nāma viprāṇāṃ kṣatriyāṇāṃ havirbhujaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ ājyapā nāma śūdrāṇāṃ tu sukālinaḥ somapāstu kaveḥ putrā haviṣmanto'ṅgiraḥsutāḥ | pulastyasyājyapāḥ putrā vasiṣṭhasya sukālinaḥ
translation: The son of a sage named Kavi, named Havismanta, is the Soma-drinker among the brahmin (priestly) class and the fire-offering performer among the kshatriya (warrior) class. The son of Vasistha, named Ajyapaa, is the ghee-offering performer among the vaishya (merchant) class and the cow-dung offering performer among the shudra (servant) class. Similarly, Pulastyaha's son Ajyapaa is the ghee-offering performer among them.

sloka: vasanto grīṣmo varṣāḥ | te devā ṛtavaḥ śaraddhemantaḥ śiśiraste pitaro ya
translation: The seasons are vasants (spring), grishmas (summer), varshas (monsoons), and shraddhas (autumn) and the pitrs (ancestors) are associated with the shishiras (winters).

sloka: kāma eṣa krodha eṣa rajoguṇasamudbhavaḥ | mahāśano mahāpāpmā viddhyenamiha vairiṇam ||
translation: This is desire, this is anger, born from the quality of passion; a great consumer and sinful, know this to be the enemy here.

sloka: kāmamāśritya duṣpūraṃ dambhamānamadānvitāḥ | mohādgṛhītvāsadgrāhānpravartante'śucivratāḥ ||
translation: Desiring sensual pleasures, emboldened by arrogance and pride, they adopt unholy habits, driven by delusion.

sloka: ahan vṛtraṃ vṛtrataraṃ vyaṃsamindro vajreṇa mahatā vadhena | skandhāṃsīva kuliśenā vivṛkṇā'hi: śayata upapṛk pṛthivyāḥ ||
translation:
I, Indra, with my great thunderbolt,
did split apart the mightiest Vritra,
like a woodcutter chops down trees,
or a smith flattens metal on an anvil.
He lay fallen on the earth.

sloka: tava cyautnāni vajrahasta tāni nava yatpuro navatiṃ ca sadyaḥ niveśane śatatamāviveṣīrahañca vartraṃ namucimutāhan
translation:
Your thunderous fists, O wielder of the vajra,
Daily scrutinize and protect the nine and ninety,
In an instant, at the most supreme installation.
And swiftly destroy the enemy named Namuchi.

sloka: śateṣu jāyate śūraḥ sahasreṣu ca paṇḍitaḥ | vaktā śatasahasreṣu dātā bhavati vā na vā ||
translation: "In hundred (battles) a hero is born, in thousands a scholar; (and) in ten thousands a speaker (or advocate), or perhaps even a giver."

sloka: kuṭumbabharaṇāddravyaṃ yatkiṃcidatiricyate | taddeyaṃ upahṛtyānyaddadaddoṣaṃ avāpnuyāt | | | |
translation: One incurs no fault by using for domestic purposes any material thing that has been acquired rightfully, over and above what one needs.

sloka: indriyaprītyarthasya tu bhikṣaṇamanimittam | na tadādriyeta ::: yoktā ca dharmayukteṣu dravyaparigraheṣu ca ::: pratipādayitā ca tīrthe :::
translation: Seeking alms for the satisfaction of the senses is the incentive, but one should not become attached to it. One should also teach and provide proper resources to those who are engaged in dharmic activities and the collection of materials at sacred pilgrimage sites.

sloka: yantā cātīrthe yato na bhayaṃ syāt ::: saṃgrahītā ca manuṣyān :::
translation: Where there is no fear in crossing, and crowds are gathered,

sloka: deśataḥ kālataḥ śaucataḥ samyak pratigrahītṛta iti dānāni pratipādayati :::
translation: "He (the guru) lays down that gifts should be given in accordance with proper time, place, and purity, as well as the worthiness of the recipient."

sloka: mekhalādhāraṇabhaikṣacaryadaṇḍasamidādhānopasparśanaprātarabhivādā nityam
translation: Wearing a sacred thread, carrying a begging bowl and a stick, and paying daily obeisance early in the morning.

sloka: brahma jñānaṃ tapo vā ācarati arjayatyavaśyam| upanayanānantaraṃ niyamaṃ kṛtvā guroḥ sannidhausthitvā sāṅgavedādhyayanaṃ karoti yaḥ | sa dbividhaḥ upakurvvāṇaḥ naiṣṭhikaśca | prathamāśramī |
translation: One who practices austerity and acquires brahma knowledge, having immediately taken the vow and being in the presence of the guru, performs saṅgaveda learning. Such a person is of two types - one who is engaged in auxiliary duties and the other who is devoted to asceticism; (he is) a first stage grahastha (householder).

sloka: codito guruṇā nityaṃ apracodita eva vā | kuryādadhyayane yatnaṃ ācāryasya hiteṣu ca | | | |
translation: Should be devoted to the guru daily, either instructed or not; one should always make effort in study and serving the teacher's interests.

sloka: uṣitvaivaṃ gurukule dvijo'dhītyāvabudhya ca | trayīṃ sāṅgopaniṣadaṃ yāvadarthaṃ yathābalam || ||
translation: Living in the guru's home and realizing it's time to leave, the twice-born one (student) should assimilate the Trayi (Rigveda, Yajurveda, Samaveda) along with the associated Upanishads to the best of their abilities.

sloka: vedayajñairahīnānāṃ praśastānāṃ svakarmasu | brahmacāryāharedbhaikṣaṃ gṛhebhyaḥ prayato'nvaham | | | | guroḥ kule na bhikṣeta na jñātikulabandhuṣu | alābhe tvanyagehānāṃ pūrvaṃ pūrvaṃ vivarjayet | | | | sarvaṃ vāpi caredgrāmaṃ pūrvoktānāṃ asaṃbhave | niyamya prayato vācaṃ abhiśastāṃstu varjayet | | | |
translation: Without participating in prescribed rituals, one should not enjoy the fruits of their own actions. A student should beg for alms only from the teacher's home, not from relatives or clan members. In times of scarcity, one may beg from others, but initially, they should avoid it. If there is no choice, one may beg from all in the village while adhering to previously mentioned guidelines. One should strictly control their speech and refrain from harsh words.

sloka: brahmacārī vratī nityaṃ nityaṃ dīkṣāparo vaśī | gurucchāyānugo nityamadhīyānaḥ suyantritaḥ | avicālyavratopetaṃ kṛtyaṃ kurvanvasetsadā ||
translation: A perpetual brahmachari, always engaged in the vow of celibacy, ever seeking initiation, self-controlled, constantly under the guidance of the guru, constantly engaged in learning, and with an unfailing vow, should always perform his duties.

sloka: suśīlo mitabhugdakṣaḥ śraddadhāno jitendriyaḥ | yāvadarthaṃ vyavaharetstrīṣu strīnirjiteṣu ca || ||
translation: A virtuous man, with good friends and allies, full of faith, and one who has conquered his senses; so long as he engages in activities for the sake of Dharma, Artha, and Kama with women who are already won over, as well as with those who are not.

sloka: vasanneko japannekaḥ sarvānvedānyudhiṣṭhira | ekasminneva cācārye śuśrūṣurmalapaṅkavān ||
translation: Like a lotus leaf in water, unattached and unsullied, Udhishthira, thus should one diligently serve a single spiritual teacher, disregarding all other teachings.

sloka: śayyāsane'dhyācarite śreyasā na samāviśet | śayyāsanasthaścaivainaṃ pratyutthāyābhivādayet | | | | ūrdhvaṃ prāṇā hyutkrāmanti yūnaḥ sthavira āyati | pratyutthānābhivādābhyāṃ punastānpratipadyate | | | |
translation: On a bed or seat, only auspicious actions should be performed; one should not become entirely engrossed in it. Even if seated, one should greet (the other) upon getting up; with standing and greeting, youth and old alike regain their energy.

sloka: śreyaḥsu guruvadvṛttiṃ nityaṃ eva samācaret | guruputreṣu cāryeṣu guroścaiva svabandhuṣu | | | | bālaḥ samānajanmā vā śiṣyo vā yajñakarmaṇi | adhyāpayangurusuto guruvanmānaṃ arhati | | | | yathā khanankhanitreṇa naro vāryadhigacchati | tathā gurugatāṃ vidyāṃ śuśrūṣuradhigacchati | | | |

varjayenmadhu māṃsaṃ ca gandhaṃ mālyaṃ rasānstriyaḥ | śuktāni yāni sarvāṇi prāṇināṃ caiva hiṃsanam | | | | abhyaṅgaṃ añjanaṃ cākṣṇorupānacchatradhāraṇam | kāmaṃ krodhaṃ ca lobhaṃ ca nartanaṃ gītavādanam | | | | dyūtaṃ ca janavādaṃ ca parivādaṃ tathānṛtam | strīṇāṃ ca prekṣaṇālambhaṃ upaghātaṃ parasya ca | | | |
translation: Avoid alcohol, meat, and strong scents/garlands. All types of violence towards living beings, unkind words, and actions. Activities such as unguent application, eye makeup, wearing earrings, garlands, and applying colorful pigments. Desires, anger, greed, dancing, singing, gambling, arguments, lying, and staring at women inappropriately or attacking others.

sloka: prativedaṃ brahmacaryaṃ dvādaśābdāni pañca vā | grahaṇāntikaṃ ityeke keśāntaścaiva ṣoḍaśe | | | |
translation: "Understand 'brahmacarya' to be either twelve or five (syllables). Some say it is also called 'grahaṇāntika' and (occurs) on the sixteenth (day of lunar fortnight), or (it is signified by) a shaving of the head."

sloka: vedasvīkaraṇaṃ kṛtvā srāyādvai dattadakṣiṇaḥ | naiṣṭhiko brahmacārī vā dehāntaṃ nivasedgurau ||
translation: After completing the Vedic studies and donating his received fees to a worthy cause, either as a wandering ascetic or a devoted student, he should renounce his body at the feet of the guru.

sloka: yadi tvātyantikaṃ vāsaṃ rocayeta guroḥ kule | yuktaḥ paricaredenaṃ ā śarīravimokṣaṇāt | | | | ācārye tu khalu prete guruputre guṇānvite | gurudāre sapiṇḍe vā guruvadvṛttiṃ ācaret | | | | eteṣvavidyamāneṣu sthānāsanavihāravān | prayuñjāno'gniśuśrūṣāṃ sādhayeddehaṃ ātmanaḥ | | | |
translation: If one desires to stay permanently in the teacher's family, they should diligently follow and serve them till the release of their body. However, if the teacher has passed away, and his qualities are inherited by the son or relative, or even a servant, one should serve and follow them, considering it as service to the teacher. In the absence of these, one should engage in performing religious duties with agnihotra (fire worship) etc., thus perfecting oneself.

sloka: evaṃ carati yo vipro brahmacaryaṃ aviplutaḥ | sa gacchatyuttamasthānaṃ na ceha jāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: One who thus conducts themselves, an ascetic fully dedicated to brahmacharya, attains the highest abode and does not return (to this world).

sloka: anena vidhinā dehaṃ sādayanvijitendriyaḥ | brahmalokaṃ avāpnoti na cehājāyate punaḥ | | | |
translation: By this method, controlling the senses while enjoying the body, one attains the abode of Brahma and is not reborn.

sloka: āvasathyādhānaṃ dārakāle dāyādyakāla ekeṣām ||
translation: During their child-rearing period, becoming donors is the provision for some.

sloka: kaccid agniṣu te yukto vidhijno matimān ṛjuḥ hutam ca hoṣyamāṇam ca kāle vedayate sadā samidhaḥpāvanāḥ pūjyāḥ carmayuktāḥ parātparāḥ yuṣmān harāmi homārthaṃ asmān rakṣata sarvadā ||
translation: Are you, who are skilled in rituals and know the right procedure, constantly aware of the offering to be made at the appropriate time in the fires of sacrifice? The purifiers, worthy of worship, combined with kindling materials, superior and inferior, I carry away for the purpose of sacrificial offerings; you always protect us.

sloka: nāma vā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmaveda atharvaṇaścaturtha itihāsapurāṇaḥ pañcamo vedānāṃ vedaḥ pitryo rāśidaivo nidhirvākovākyamekāyanaṃ devavidyā brahmavidyā bhūtavidyā kṣatravidyā nakṣatravidyā sarpadevajñavidyā nāmaivaitannāmopāssveti
translation: The name of the first is Rigveda, Yajurveda the second, SamaVEDA the third, and Atharvan the fourth; the fifth is Itihāsa-Purāṇa, knowledge of beings the ancestral, divine for the common people, a single embedded Veda, [and] the knowledge of devas, Brahman, creatures, warriors, stars, serpent-deities – this is named 'name', it is not separate from the named.

sloka: mano vāva vāco bhūyo yathā vai dve vā''malake mano hyātmā mano loko mano hi brahma mana upāssveti
translation: "Indeed, the mind is verily speech, as also the world, the mind is indeed the self, the mind is the world, the mind is Brahman; one should meditate on the mind."

sloka: dhyānaṃ vāva cittādbhūyo dhyāyatīva pṛthavī dhyāyatīvāntarikṣaṃ dhyāyatīva dyaurdhyāyatīva''po dhyāyantīva parvatā dhyāyantīva devamanuṣyāstasmādya iha manuṣyāṇāṃ mahattāṃ prapnuvanti dhyānāpādā~ śā ivaiva te dhyānamupāssveti
translation: MEDITATION, indeed, is that which is to be focused upon, like a person focusing on the earth, the sky, the space, the heaven, the mountains, and other humans and celestial beings. Therefore, it is through meditation that humans of greatness here attain their greatness. One should practice this very meditation.

sloka: balaṃ vāva vijñānādbhūyo'pi ha śataṃ vijñānavatāseko balavānākampayate sa yadā balī bhavatyathotthātā bhavatyuttiṣṭhan paricaritā bhavati paricarannupasatta bhavatyupasīdandraṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati balamupāssveti
translation: Strength, indeed, is born from knowledge; even a hundred times more powerful than the strong becomes one who has knowledge. When one becomes strong, then they stand up, start acting, attend to duties, become alert, start seeing, hearing, contemplating, understanding, and focusing on strength.

sloka: annaṃ vāva balādbhūyastasmādyadyapi daśarātrārnāśrnīyādyadyu ha jīvedathavā'draṣṭā'śrotā'mantā'bodhdā'kartā'vijñātā bhavatyathānnasyā''yai draṣṭā bhavati śrotā bhavati mantā bhavati bodhdā bhavati kartā bhavati vijñātā bhavatyannamupāssveti
translation: Food is surely the foundation of strength, therefore one should always partake in it whether one is alive or a perceiver, hearer, ponderer, knower, doer, or experienced of its nature. One becomes a perceiver, hearer, ponderer, knower, doer, and experienced of its nature through food. Therefore, one should cherish and attend to food.

sloka: āpo vāvānnādbhūyasyastasmādyadā suvṛṣṭirna bhavati vyādhīyante prāṇā annaṃ kanīyo bhaviṣyatītyatha yadā suvṛṣṭirbhavatyānandinaḥ prāṇā bhavantyannaṃ bahu bhaviṣyatītyāpa evemā mūrtā yeyaṃ pṛthavī yadantarikṣaṃ mūrtā apa upāssveti
translation: The waters (of the earth), indeed, are identical with the divine vital airs. Hence, when rain doesn't occur, life-breaths (beings) waste away and food becomes scarce. But when rain does occur, life-breaths become robust and food becomes abundant. Thus, this earth, which is a form of those same waters, nourishes itself by absorbing the water into its own form.

sloka: tejo vāvādbhyo bhūyastadvā etadvāyumāgṛhnā''kāśamabhitapati tadā''hurniśocati nitapati varṣiṣyati vā iti teja eva tatpūrvaṃ darśayitvā'thāpaḥ sṛjate tadetadūrdhvābhiśca tiraścībhiśca vidyudbhirāhrādāścaranti teja upāssveti
translation: From that (source) which emits heat in excess, then seizing the vital air, it illuminates the sky, it rains, or it shines; initially, it is heat that makes this visible, and then arises the burning sensation. Above and to the sides, lightning flashes; thus, one should meditate on heat (energy).

sloka: ākāśo vāva tejaso bhūyānākāśe vai sūryā candramasāvubhau vidyunnakṣatrāṇyagnirākāśenā''hvayatyākāśena pratiśrṛṇotyākāśe ramata ākāśe na ramata ākāśe jāyata ākāśamabhijāyata ākāśamupāssveti
translation:
Space indeed originates from light,
In space the sun and moon shine,
In it reside lightning and stars,
Space is kindled by fire,
Space is what one hears in space,
Space is where one finds delight,
From space comes creation,
Space is what one is born into,
Space is what one meditates upon.

sloka: smaro vāvā''kāśādbhūyastasmādyadyapi bahava āsīranna smaranto naiva te kaṃcana śṛṇuyurnamanvīranna vijānīranyadā vāva te smareyuratha śṛṇuyuratha manvīrannatha vijānīransmareṇa vai putrānvijānāti smareṇa paśūnsmaramupāssveti
translation: The mindful one, though situated far away, is still remembered by many. Yet those who are unmindful are not remembered or recognized by them. Sometimes they may remember or recognize those who are mindful. Through being mindful, one recognizes their children and animals, and attends to them.

sloka: āśā vāva smarādbhūyasyāśeddho vai smaro mantrānadhīte karmaṇi kurute putrā~śca paśū~ścecchata imaṃ ca lokamamuṃ cecchata āśāmupāssveti
translation: The desire (of a person) indeed flourishes in recollection and meditation of the worthy one, and performs sacred rites. Both sons and cattle thrive, as well as this world and the other world, such is the nurturing of desire.

sloka: prāṇo vā āśāyā bhūyānyathā vā arā nābhau samarpitā evamasminprāṇe sarva~samarpitaṃ prāṇaḥ prāṇena yāti prāṇaḥ prāṇaṃ dadāti prāṇāya dadāti prāṇo ha pitā prāṇo mātā prāṇo bhrātā prāṇaḥ svasā prāṇa ācāryaḥ prāṇo brahmaṇaḥ
translation: The life force (prana) is the desire (asharya), or otherwise it is not located in the navel. All that is offered in this life force, goes with the life force, gives life force to the life force and to the life force gives. The life force is the father, the life force is the mother, the life force is the brother, the life force is the sister, the life force is the teacher, the life force is from Brahman.

sloka: yo vai bhūmā tatsukhaṃ nālpe sukhamasti bhūmaiva sukhaṃ bhūmā tveva vijijñāsitavya iti bhūmānaṃ bhagavo vijijñāsa iti
translation: The one who knows the ultimate reality, finds true happiness therein, not in transient things. One should inquire into that reality, the Lord himself exhorts us to understand 'Bhuma.'

sloka: yatra nānyatpaśyati nānyacchṛṇoti nānyadvijānāti sa bhūmā'tha yatrānyatpaśyatyanyacchṛṇotyanyadvijānāti tadalpaṃ yo vai bhūmā tadamṛtamatha yadalpaṃ tanmartya~sa bhagavaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti sve mahimni yadi vā na mahimnīti
translation: Where one sees nothing else, hears nothing else, and knows nothing else, that is the Infinite. Where one sees, hears, and knows something else, that is limited. The impermanent is surely mortal, but the Infinite is immortal. Where is He established, in His own greatness or not in it?

sloka: aparābādhamakleśaṃ prayatnenārjītaṃ dhanam | svalpaṃ vā vipulaṃ vāpi deyamityabhidīyate ||
translation: The affliction caused by harm can be acquired rid of through diligent effort, whether it is meager or vast, and is referred to as 'that which should be given.'

sloka: vyākhyā api tantrasya guṇaḥ| tābhirapi tantramalaṅikrayate | tāśca pañcadaśa prakārā |
translation: The explanation is also a quality of the Tantra, with those ( fifteen qualities) the Tantra is adorned.

sloka: indro dadhīco asthabhirvṛtrāṇyapratiṣkutaḥ jaghāna navatīrnava
translation: Indra, unshaken, with his mighty weapons, destroyed ninety waters (of the enemy).

sloka: ichannaśvasya yacchiraḥ parvateṣvapaśritam tada vidaccharyaṇāvati
translation: The peak of Mount Yachandra, which desireful serpents dwell upon, was exposed.

sloka: maghavān yāta bhadraṃ vo dadhyāñcamṛṣisattamam vidyāvratatapaḥsāraṃ gātraṃ yācata mā ciram
translation: Maghavan, (please) go soon to obtain the best offering of curds, the result of a wise and austere brahmin's penance.

sloka: sa vā adhigato dadhyaṅṅaśvibhyāṃ brahma niṣkalam yad vā aśvaśiro nāma yatoramaratāṃ vyadhāt
translation: He indeed attained, through intense meditation, the undivided Brahman, also known as Ashwattha (the eternal); the dispeller of the fear of birth and death.

sloka: dadhyaṅṅātharvaṇastvaṣṭre varmābhedyaṃ madātmakam viśvarūpāya yat prādāt tvaṣṭā yat tvamadhāstataḥ
translation: You, Atman free from decay, which Arvan gave

sloka: yuṣmabhyaṃ yācato'śvibhyāṃ dharmajño'ṅgāni dāsyati tatastairāyudhaśreṣṭho viśvakarmavinirmitaḥ yena vṛtraśiro hartā mattejaupabṛṃhitaḥ
translation: "If asked by you, the knowledgeable one will give you (plural) pieces of equipment. Then, the best among weapons, created by Viswakarma, will be used to strike and forcibly remove Indra's thunderbolt from Vritra's head."

sloka: tasmin vinihate yūyaṃ tejo'strāyudhasampadaḥ bhūyaḥ prapsyatha bhadraṃ vo na hiṃsanti ca matpurān
translation: "In that fallen , you will obtain again your splendid weaponry, blessings to you. They do not harm my grandchildren."

sloka: etaddhyevākṣaraṃ brahma etaddhyevākṣaraṃ param | etaddhyevākṣaraṃ jñātvā yo yadicchati tasya tat || ||
translation: This syllable is Brahman, this syllable is the supreme. Knowing this syllable, one gets whatever one desires.

sloka: etadvai satyakāma paraṃ cāparaṃ ca brahma yadoṅkāraḥ |
translation: This alone is the ultimate reality, both the manifest and unmanifest Brahman, which is the sound 'Om'.

sloka: dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca sthitaṃ ca yacca sacca tyacca || ||
translation: Two forms of Brahman exist, the tangible and the intangible, the mortal and the immortal, the stationary and the moving, the true and the untrue.

sloka: anyacchreyo'nyadutaiva preyaste ubhe nānārthe puruṣa~ sinītaḥ | tayoḥ śreya ādadānasya sādhu bhavati hīyate'rthādya u preyo vṛṇīte || ||
translation: Choosing another's advantage over one's own in every case, and being intent on different purposes, between these two, the person who adopts the beneficial one, becomes virtuous and does not lose merit or preference.

sloka: śreyaśca preyaśca manuṣyametaḥ tau samparītya vivinakti dhīraḥ | śreyo hi dhīro'bhi preyaso vṛṇīte preyo mando yogakṣemādvṛṇīte || ||
translation: The wise one discerns between what is auspicious and what is pleasing to oneself, after examining them. Indeed, the wise person chooses what is auspicious, while the ignorant person chooses what is pleasing and brings about welfare and self-control.

sloka: sa tvaṃ priyānpriyarūpāṃśca kāmān abhidhyāyannaciketo'tyasrākṣīḥ | naitā~ sṛṅkāṃ vittamayīmavāpto yasyāṃ majjanti bahavo manuṣyāḥ || ||
translation: You, who are always intent on pursuing dear ones and their charming forms, yet remain aloof; those desires, filled with avarice, are not the means for you to attain liberation, in which many humans drown.

sloka: dūramete viparīte viṣūcī avidyā yā ca vidyeti jñātā | vidyābhīpsinaṃ naciketasaṃ manye na tvā kāmā bahavo'lolupanta || ||
translation: At a distance or in reverse, like a mirage, is ignorance which is called knowledge; I think Naciketa is not one who desires many things, attached to desire.

sloka: avidyāyāmantare vartamānāḥ svayaṃ dhīrāḥ paṇḍitaṃmanyamānāḥ | dandramyamāṇāḥ pariyanti mūḍhā andhenaiva nīyamānā yathāndhāḥ || ||
translation: Living in their self-created ignorance, they consider themselves wise; like blind men led by a blind leader, they wander aimlessly.

sloka: na sāmparāyaḥ pratibhāti bālaṃ pramādyantaṃ vittamohena mūḍham | ayaṃ loko nāsti para iti mānī punaḥ punarvaśamāpadyate me || ||
translation: "A foolish person intoxicated by wealth does not notice the end is near. This world, considering itself separate, keeps falling again and again under my control."

sloka: ya ete pitṛdevānāmayane vedanirmite śāstreṇa cakṣuṣā veda janastho'pi na muhyati ādāvante janānāṃ sadbahirantaḥ parāvaram jñānaṃ jñeyaṃ vaco vācyaṃ tamo jyotistvayaṃ svayam
translation: One who, even while dwelling among people, is not deluded by the complex text of the Vedas concerning the eternal divine principle of pities, knows that knowledge, word, and object are all manifestations of the supreme consciousness, the distinction between light and dark.

sloka: agniḥ sūryo divā prāhṇaḥ śuklo rākottaraṃ svarāṭ viśvo'tha taijasaḥ prājñasturya ātmā samanvayāt devayānamidaṃ prāhurbhūtvā bhūtvānupūrvaśaḥ ātmayājyupaśāntātmā hyātmastho na nivartate
translation: "They say this is the divinely established sacrificial fire, Agni, the sun during daytime, independent Surya, the white one higher than Roopa (Rakottaram), all-pervading and conscious Tajasa, highly revered Atma (soul) because of being interconnected. Becoming and ceasing to be in succession, the soulful Atma, ever-present and not retreating, is the self-offering, self-consummating, and self-peaceful."

sloka: dravyasūkṣmavipākaśca dhūmo rātrirapakṣayaḥ ayanaṃ dakṣiṇaṃ somo darśa oṣadhivīrudhaḥ annaṃ reta iti kṣmeśa pitṛyānaṃ punarbhavaḥ ekaikaśyenānupūrvaṃ bhūtvā bhūtveha jāyate
translation: Subtle effects of substances, smoke, night, decline, southern direction, moon, Darsha (a star), herbs and plants, food, semen, these are the causes of the birth in the world; each arising in a novel way, they take birth here again.

sloka: tadya iha ramaṇīyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte ramaṇīyāṃ yonimāpadyeranbrāhmaṇayoniṃ vā kṣatriyayoniṃ vā vaiśyayoniṃ vātha ya iha kapūyacaraṇā abhyāśo ha yatte kapūyāṃ yonimāpadyeran śvayoniṃ vā sūkarayoniṃ vā caṇḍālayoniṃ vā ||
translation: To be engaged here and now in delightful actions or to adopt conduct that leads to delightful wombs, namely those of a Brahmin, Kshatriya, Vaishya, or even that of a dog, pig, or Chandala.

sloka: tadantarapratipattau raṃhati sampariṣvaktaḥ praśnanirūpaṇābhyām
translation: In the process of directly realizing that, it is impelled by precisely formulated questions and discussions.

sloka: samānā cāsṛtyupakramādamṛtatvaṃ cānupoṣya
translation: Equal being in the initiation and nourishing the imperishable (immortality) as well.

sloka: śuklakṛṣṇe gatī hyete jagataḥ śāśvate mate | ekayā yātyanāvṛttimanyayāvartate punaḥ
translation:
The white and black paths of this eternal world,
One leads to the end, the other to return.

sloka: agne devā~ ihā vaha sādayā yoniṣu triṣu | pari bhūṣa piba ṛtunā ||
translation: "O Agni, bring here, to the sacred ceremonies, the gods; adorn and drink with Soma."

sloka: dakṣiṇaṃ tveva prathamaṃ vijñāyate pitā vā eṣo'gnīnāṃ yaddakṣiṇaḥ putro gārhapatyaḥ pautra āhavanīyastasmādevaṃ paryukṣet
translation: Know the southern direction to be the first, as it is so for the fires; the father is the sacrificial fire in the south, the son is the garhapatya fire, and the grandson is the ahavaniya fire. Therefore, one should duly honor (nourish) them.

sloka: ta eva hi trayo lokāsta eva traya āśramāḥ | ta eva hi trayo vedāsta evoktāstrayo'gnayaḥ | |
translation: These very three are the worlds, these very three are the ashramas. These very three are the Vedas, and these three are also the Agnihotras.

sloka: pitā vai gārhapatyo'gnirmātāgnirdakṣiṇāḥ smṛtāḥ | gururāhavanīyastu sāgnitretā garīyasī ||
translation: The father is considered as the creator and distributor of the domestic fire, while the teacher is regarded as more esteemed, being the invoker of the sacrificial fire.

sloka: triṣvapramādyanneteṣu trīllolokān vijayedgṛhī | dīpyamānaḥ svavapuṣāḥ devavadyivi modate ||
translation: Victorious in the three-fold primordial wisdom, illuminating the three worlds with his own radiance, delighting like a god – such is the state of one's being.

sloka: nṛyajño'tithipūjanam
translation: Worship of the Lord during specific days/occasions.

sloka: kṛtvaitadbalikarmaivaṃ atithiṃ pūrvaṃ āśayet | bhikṣāṃ ca bhikṣave dadyādvidhivadbrahmacāriṇe | | | |
translation: Perform this heroic deed first - welcome the guest; then, respectfully give alms to the mendicant monk.

sloka: vidyātapaḥsamṛddheṣu hutaṃ vipramukhāgniṣu | nistārayati durgācca mahataścaiva kilbiṣāt | | | |
translation: "In places abundant with knowledge and spiritual practice, the fire offered by the pure-hearted (brahmin) burns away greatly the sins of both the ordinary and the severe kind, as well as those that are difficult to get rid of."

sloka: tapasah: tatmahinaajāyataekam
translation: Through austerity, we meditate on the unique, unborn self.

sloka: divyo hyamūrtaḥ puruṣaḥ sabāhyābhyantaro hyajaḥ apraṇo hyamanāḥ śubhro hyakṣarātparataḥ paraḥ
translation: The divine, unborn being is inner and outside, unsullied, without any distinctive marks, shining from itself, superior to all.

sloka: devānāṃ pūrvye yuge'sataḥ sadajāyata || devānāṃ yuge prathame'sataḥ sadajāyata | tadāśā anvajāyanta taduttānapadaspari ||
translation: In the first century of the previous yuga, the original being of the devas was born. In the first century of the current yuga, the original being of the devas was also born, and then the Āśās were produced from them and around them.

sloka: ekam sat vipra bahudhā vadanti
translation: "Truth is one, but the wise call it by various names."

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tato vai sadajāyata | tadātmāna~ svayamakuruta | tasmāttatsukṛtamucyata iti | yadvai tat sukṛtam | raso vai saḥ |
translation: "In the beginning, this was non-existent. Then existence emerged from it. The Self, of its own accord, initiated this. Hence it is called 'created by the Self.' That which created it is indeed the Rasa (essence)."

sloka: asadvā idamagra āsīt | tadāhuḥ kiṃ tadasadāsīdityṛṣayo vāva te'gre'sadāsīt
translation: "In the beginning, this was non-existent. How, then, could it have become existent later?" - say the seers (of truth) who were themselves always existent.

sloka: so'yaṃ puruṣaḥ prajāpatirakāmayata bhūyāntsyāṃ prajāyeyeti so'śrāmyatsa tapo'tapyata sa śrāntastepāno brahmaiva prathamamasṛjata
translation: Therefore, this Purusha, Prajapati, desired 'Let there be an increase in the creation'. He practiced austerity and, fatigued, first created Brahma.

sloka: naiveha kiṃcanāgra āsīn mṛtyunaivedamāvṛtamāsīdaśanāyayā'śanāyā hi mṛtyus tanmano'kurutā''tmanvī syāmiti | so'rcannacarat tasyārcata āpo'jāyantārcate vai me kamabhūditi | ||
translation:
None has ever dwelt here in the past free from death,
nor will there be anyone in the future who is free from it.
This body is certain to be covered with impermanence due to birth and decay.
Therefore, one should perform actions only for the satisfaction of their own mind,
just as the wise person performs rituals for the satisfaction of the gods.

sloka: nāsa̭dāsīnno sadā̭sīttadānīm nāsīdrajo no vyo̭mā paro yat| kimāva̭rīva: kuha kasya śarmannaṃbha: kimā̭sīdgaha̭naṃ gabhīram ||
translation: You are never non-existent, always existent; you are the same in the past, present and future. Is there any ruler other than you? Is there any cause for this diversity, any support for this world order, any source of birth and growth?

sloka: na mṛtyurā̭sīdamṛtaṃ na tarhi na rātryā ahna̭ āsītpraketaḥ| ānī̭davātaṃ svadhayā tadekaṃ tasmā̭ddhānyanna paraḥ kiñcanāsa̭||
translation: "Death did not exist, nor immortality, nor was there then the division between night and day. That one breathed without distinction, through its own energy. There was nothing else beyond it."

sloka: tama̭ āsīttama̭sā gūl̤hamagrḙ'praketaṃ sa̭lilaṃ sarva̭mā idaṃ| tucchyenābhvapi̭hitaṃ yadāsīttapa̭sastanma̭hinā jā̭yataika̭ṃ|| ||
translation: The supreme darkness was first covered by a luminous salila (primordial liquid). It became manifest at the beginning of creation, when only the one unborn (purusha) existed.

sloka: kāmastadagre sama̭vartatādhi mana̭so reta̭: prathamaṃ yadāsī̭t| sato bandhumasa̭ti nira̭vindan hṛdi pratīṣyā̭ kavayo̭ manīṣā||
translation: At the forefront of desire, when the mind is fully concentrated, and the first drop of semen has arisen, then one should immediately expel it; such is the injunction of the wise.

sloka: tiraścīno vita̭to raśmirḙṣāmadhaḥ svi̭dāsī dupari̭ svidāsī tat| retodhā ā̭sanmahimāna̭ āsantsvadhā āvastātpraya̭tiḥ parastā̭t||
translation: Three leaders, free from desire, have risen among us in the battlefield, making it fragrant with the scent of excellence. Like a fruit sweets to taste, they stand before us. We watched their approach; they have now arrived near us.

sloka: ko addhā vḙda ka iha pravo̭catkuta ājā̭tā kuta̭ iyaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭiḥ| arvāgdevā asya visarja̭ne॒nāthā॒ ko vḙda॒ yata̭ āba॒bhūva̭ ||
translation:
Who is powerful enough to reveal truly
What is this creation, whence it has come?
By whose command did this universe spring into being?
Who in the past has been able to describe his origin?

sloka: i॒yaṃ visṛ̭ṣṭi॒ryata̭ āba॒bhūva॒ yadi̭ vā da॒dhe yadi̭ vā॒ na| yo a॒syādhya̭kṣaḥ para॒me vyo̭ma॒ntso a॒ṅga vḙda॒ yadi̭ vā॒ na veda̭|| ||
translation: "Whether it (the universe) originated from expansion or from something solid, or came into being without any support; whoever is the observer of its creation, if there is one; or whether there isn't one who knows it."

sloka: iṣṭaprāpti aniṣṭapariharyor alaukikam upāyam yo grantho vedayati sa vedaḥ
translation: The text that reveals an extraordinary means to obtain the desired and remove the undesired is called Veda.

sloka: mantra brahmanyor vedanāmadheyam
translation: The designation of the Vedas for the Brahman resides in the mantras.

sloka: brahmamukhanirgatadharmmajñāpakaśāstram iti purāṇam
translation: The scripture that reveals the nature of dharma as originating from the source of Brahman.

sloka: tasmādṛca: sāma yajūṃṣi dīkṣā
translation: Therefore, hymns (are) Rigveda, SamaVEDA, and YajurVEDA, and the initiation ritual.

sloka: etasya vā mahato bhūtasya ni:śvasitametad yad ṛgvedo yajurveda: sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa
translation: The breath of this vast being, that is the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvangirasa.

sloka: dharmabrahmapratipādakamapauruṣeyavākyam iti vedāntaśāstram
translation: The statement elucidating dharma and Brahman is called Vedanta shastra.

sloka: na vedaśāstrādanyattu kiṃcicchāstraṃ hi vidyate | niḥsṛtaṃ sarvaśāstraṃ tu vedaśāstrāt sanātanam ||
translation: Nothing exists as a separate teaching apart from the Vedas, since all other teachings are ultimately derived from it. The eternal source of all knowledge is the Veda shastra.

sloka: darśayataś caivaṃ pratyakṣānumāne |
translation: "and also demonstrated directly and personally" or "made it evident through personal experience" (depending on context)

sloka: mātāpitrorgurau mitre vinīte copakāriṇi | dīnānāthaviśiṣṭebhyo dattantu saphalaṃ bhavet ||
translation: May mother, father, teachers, elders, friends and well-wishers bestow auspiciousness upon the destitute and most excellent among the needy.

sloka: śrotriyāya daridrāya gṛhasthāyāgnihotriṇe| putradārābhibhūtāya tathā hyanupakāriṇe|| evaṃvidheṣu dātavyā na samṛddheṣu bhārata|
translation: To the worthy and poor teacher, to the housholder performing fire-rituals, to one who is overwhelmed by children and wife, as well as to those who are not reciprocating - such persons deserve to be given to, not the wealthy.

sloka: dhūrte vandini mande ca kuvaidye kitave śaṭhe | cāṭucāraṇacaurabhyo dattaṃ bhavati niṣphalam ||
translation: Given to a deceitful person, or offered to those who are unworthy, mean-minded, dishonest, or excessively greedy, it becomes fruitless.

sloka: avyaktādvyaktayaḥ sarvāḥ prabhavantyaharāgame | rātryāgame pralīyante tatraivāvyaktasaṃjñake || || parastasmāttu bhāvo'nyo'vyakto'vyaktātsanātanaḥ | yaḥ sa sarveṣu bhūteṣu naśyatsu na vinaśyati || || avyakto'kṣara ityuktastamāhuḥ paramāṃ gatim |
translation:
From the unmanifest to the manifest all (things) emerge in the course of a day,
And then merge back into the unmanifest at the arrival of night, in that same unmanifest;
Apart from this, there is no other being, eternal and imperishable,
Which exists in all beings, not perishing even when they are destroyed.
That which is called unmanifest, indestructible, is also known as the supreme destination.

sloka: taddha tadvanaṃ nāma tadvanamityupāsitavyaṃ sa ya etadevaṃ vedābhihaina~ sarvāṇi bhūtāni saṃvāñchanti || ||
translation: That is called the 'name of a group (or kind)', which should be venerated as 'the name of a name'. One who knows that alone, connects with all beings.

sloka: tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ
translation: "Spoken in the presence of another woman, similar to his beloved" or "Just like speaking to his beloved, spoken in the presence of another woman" would be an accurate translation of "tadyathā priyāya striyā striyāsaṃparṣvaktaḥ".

sloka: priyo hi jananinotyārthaṃ aham sa ca mam priyaḥ
translation: Dear to them, I am indeed for some meaningful purpose, and so is he dear to me.

sloka: pañca sūnā gṛhasthasya cullī peṣaṇyupaskaraḥ | kaṇḍanī codakumbhaśca badhyate yāstu vāhayan
translation: Five carts are required by a householder, namely: asses for plowing, cows for milking, women for service, dogs for guarding, and birds for messaging. But these are bound (restricted) by him who is engaged in spiritual practices.

sloka: adhyāpanaṃ brahmayajñaḥ pitṛyajñastu tarpaṇam | homo daivo balirbhautī nṛyajño'tithipūjanam ||
translation: Teaching is the Brahmin's sacrifice, the sacrificial rite for ancestors is tarpanam (offering libations to ancestors), homa is the divine offering, strength is the warrior's sacrifice, and human's sacrifice is the worship of designated occasions.

sloka: tadyadagnau juhoti sa devayajño yadbaliṅkaroti sa bhūtayajño yatpitṛbhyo dadāti sa pitṛyajño yatsvādhyāyamadhīyate sa brahmayajño yanmanuṣyebhyo dadāti sa manuṣyayajña iti tānetānyajñānaharahaḥ kurvīta
translation: "What he offers in the fire is the divine sacrifice, what he dedicates to embellishments is the sacrificial offering to elements, what he gives to the ancestors is the sacrifice to ancestors, what he studies and teaches is the sacrifice to Brahma, what he gives to people is the sacrifice to humans. Thus, these are the five daily sacrifices that should be performed."

sloka: tadvidhiprasaṅgena pañcamahāyajñānvidhatte
translation: Performs the fifth major sacrifice, known as Mahayajna, due to its association with the prescribed procedure (of Vedic rituals).

sloka: pañca vā ete mahāyajñā: satati pratāyante satati saṃtiṣṭhante devayajña: pitṛyajño bhūtayajño manuṣyayajño brahmayajño iti iti
translation: Five are these great sacrifices: daily they are offered up, daily they are established - deity sacrifice, ancestor sacrifice, animal sacrifice, human sacrifice, and knowledge sacrifice.

sloka: tatra devayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadagnau juhotyapi samidhaṃ taddevayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti puroḍāśādihavirmukhyaṃ tadalābhe samidhamapyagnau devānuddiśañjuhotīti yatso'yaṃ devayajñaḥ
translation: The characteristic of a divine sacrifice is that fuel is offered in the fire; this is called divine sacrifice, as a portion of the offering such as a cooked grain or libation is dedicated to the gods by casting it into the fire. This is the definition of a divine sacrifice.

sloka: bhūtayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbhūtebhyo bali~ harati tadbhūtayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The characteristic of a sacrifice to elements is to offer (harati) oblations (bali) to the elements (bhutebhyah). This is how a sacrifice to the elements (bhutayajna) exists (samsthitae).

sloka: manuṣyayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yadbrāhmaṇebhyo'nnaṃ dadāti tanmanuṣyayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti
translation: The characteristic of a human sacrifice (manuṣya-yajña) is described as that which is given to Brahmins and thereby sustains it.

sloka: brahmayajñasya lakṣaṇamāha yatsvādhyāyamadhīyītaikāmapyṛcaṃ yaju: sāmaṃ vā tadbrahmayajña: saṃtiṣṭhate iti svasyāsādhāraṇatvena pitṛpitāmahādiparamparayā prāptā vedaśākhā svādhyāyaḥ tatra vidyamānamṛgādīnāmanyatamamekamapi vākyamadhīyīteti yatso'yaṃ brahmayajñaḥ
translation: The characteristics of the Brahma sacrifice are described as that which is studied, namely one Veda chapter – either Yajur, Rig, or Sama. It stands established through its being commonly received as such in the tradition of forefathers, beginning with one's own father. In it, even if only a single verse or a sentence is studied, it becomes the Brahma sacrifice.

sloka: devatoddeśena hi dravyatyāgo yāgaḥ| sa eva tyajyamānadravyasyāgnau prakṣepāddhoma ityucyate|
translation: The ritual sacrifice referred to as "yaaga" is the relinquishment of materials offered through the process of devatoddesha (designation of deities). It is called "prakshepah" when the designated material is thrown into the fire.

sloka: darśapūrṇamāsayoścatvāra ṛtvijo'dhvaryurbrahmā hotāgnīdhra iti
translation: The four priests, namely the Darsha-Purnamasya, Adhvaryu, Brahma, and Hotr, along with the Agnihdra.

sloka: paśūnāṃ dravyahaviṣāmṛk‌sāmayajuṣāṃ tathā| ṛtvijāṃ dakṣiṇāyāśca saṃyogo yajña ucyate|| ||
translation: The union of (1) oblations containing substances that are either edible for animals, toxic, or agreeable, and (2) priests and the sacrificial fees paid to them is called a Yajna.

sloka: ayam yajna vishvasya bhuvanasya nabheehi
translation: This sacrifice is the navel of all creatures in this world.

sloka: gṛhasthasya kriyātyāgo vratatyāgo vaṭorapi tapasvino grāmasevā bhikṣorindriyalolatā āśramāpasadā hyete khalvāśramaviḍambanāḥ devamāyāvimūḍhāṃstānupekṣetānukampayā
translation: Of a householders' duties abandonment or observance, even that of a mendicant in the forest, village service, or the engrossing in one's own sensory pleasures; these are indeed pretensions of an ascetic life and a delusion of the divine power, which should be disregarded with indifference and compassion towards those who are bewildered by such deception.

sloka: kṛttikāsu mahābhāge pāyasena sasarpiṣā| santarpya brāhmaṇānsādhū~llokānāpnotyanuttamān||
translation: Filled with delight, she (Ahalya) offered libations of milk to the Krittikas. Having satisfied the worthy brahmins and people, she attained excellent spiritual success.

sloka: ṛcāṃ tva: poṣamāste pupuṣvāngāyatraṃ tvo gāyati śakvarīṣu | brahmā tvo vadati jātavidyāṃ yajñasya mātrāṃ vi mimīta u tvaḥ ||
translation: May prosperity and growth be yours, as you travel among the blooming plants; may Brahma speak to you about the extent of knowledge in the sacrifice.

sloka: avināśi tu tadviddhi yena sarvamidaṃ tatam | vināśamavyayasyāsya na kaścitkartumarhati || ||
translation: That is indestructible, know this; by which all this is pervaded. No one can bring about the destruction of the imperishable.

sloka: tatko vṛtraḥ| megha iti nairuktāḥ | tvāṣṭro'sura ityaitihāsikāḥ | apāṃ ca jyotiṣaśca miśrībhāvakarmaṇo varṣakarma jāyate | tatropamārthena yuddhavarṇā bhavanti |
translation: The one who is called Vrtra, named "Megha" in the Nairukti school, and known as Twashtra in epics, his actions result in the mixing of water and light, giving rise to the function of rain-giving. It is through this very substance that battle descriptions appear (in the Rigveda).

sloka: iṣumātramiṣumātravvi~ṣvaṅṅavardhata sa imāllo~kānavṛṇodyadimāllo~kānavṛṇottadvṛtrasya vṛtratvantasmādindro'bibhedapi
translation: "Only through Isumatramișumati did the lotus-eyed Indra swell in strength, for the purpose of becoming the slayer of the Vṛtra with a thousand eyes, hence he pierced it."

sloka: atṛpṇuvantaṃ viyatamabudhyamabudhyamānaṃ suṣupāṇamindra sapta prati pravata āśayānamahiṃ vajreṇa vi riṇā aparvan
translation: Perceiving all-pervading consciousness, awakened and still in deep meditation, Indra sends forth with his thunderbolt, again and again, towards that unfailing target.
