sloka: samudrajyeṣṭhāḥ salilasya madhyātpunānā yantyaniviśamānāḥ indro yā vajrī vṛṣabho rarāda tā āpo devīrihamāmavantu
translation: "O supreme over the ocean, those who wander in the midst of water, let Indra, the wielder of thunder, cause them to enter the abode of Devi."

sloka: ahiṃsā satyam asteyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | etaṃ sāmāsikaṃ dharmaṃ cāturvarṇye'bravīnmanuḥ | | | |
translation: Non-violence, truthfulness, non-stealing, cleanliness, and control of the senses. These, instructed by Manu, are the complete duties for all four social classes.

sloka: dhṛtiḥ kṣamā damo'steyaṃ śaucam indriyanigrahaḥ | dhīrvidyā satyam akrodho daśakaṃ dharmalakṣaṇam | | | |
translation: The ten signs of dharma are: patience, forgiveness, self-control, non-stealing, cleanliness, sense restraint, understanding, wisdom, truthfulness, and absence of anger.

sloka: paropakārāya phalanti vṛkṣāḥ paropakārāya vahanti nadyaḥ | paropakārāya duhanti gāvaḥ paropakārārthamidaṃ śarīram || satyaṃ vada | dharmañcara | svādhyāyānmā pramadaḥ | ācāryāya priyaṃ dhanamāhṛtya prajātantuṃ mā vyavacchetsīḥ | satyānna pramaditavyam | dharmānna pramaditavyam | kuśalānna pramaditavyam | bhūtyai na pramaditavyam | svādhyāyapravacanābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam || ||
translation:
Trees bear fruit for others' benefit, so do rivers flow;
Cows yield milk for others' use, this body is meant to serve the same end.
Speak the truth, follow dharma, never neglect your studies,
Give generously to the teacher, don't deprive the fetus of its life in the womb,
Never be negligent about truth, dharma, auspiciousness, or prosperity,
Nor should you be neglectful regarding study and recitation.

sloka: devapitṛkāryābhyāṃ na pramaditavyam | mātṛdevo bhava | pitṛdevo bhava | ācāryadevo bhava | atithidevo bhava | yānyanavadyāni karmāṇi tāni sevitavyāni | no itarāṇi | yānyasmākaṃ sucaritāni | tāni tvayopāsyāni | no itarāṇi || || sukhārthinaḥ kuto vidyā nāsti vidyārthinaḥ sukham | sukhārthī vā tyajedvidyāṃ vidyārthī vā tyajet sukham ||
translation: One should not be negligent towards the duties of the gods, ancestors, and teachers. Consider them as your own god. Perform only those actions that are non-harmful. Do not engage in other activities. Follow whatever good deeds we have practiced. Do not follow other ones. For one seeking happiness, there is no knowledge; for one seeking knowledge, there is no happiness. One seeking happiness should give up knowledge; one seeking knowledge should give up happiness.

sloka: imaṃ vivasvate yogaṃ proktavānahamavyayam vivasvānmanave prāha manurikṣvākave'bravīt
translation: I taught this imperishable yoga to Vivasvan, Vivasvan imparted it to Manu, and Manu conveyed it to Ikshvaku.

sloka: evaṃ paramparāprāptamimaṃ rājarṣayo viduḥ sa kāleneha mahatā yogo naṣṭaḥ parantapa
translation: "Thus, transmitted through successive generations, royal sages knew this yoga, but it has been lost in time, O vanquisher of foes."

sloka: yattadadreśyamagrāhyamagotramavarṇaṃmacakṣuḥśrotraṃ tadapāṇipādam nityaṃ vibhuṃ sarvagataṃ susūkṣmaṃ tadavyayaṃ yadbhūtayoniṃ paripaśyanti dhīrāḥ
translation: That which is not visible, not graspable, has no form, cannot be grasped by the senses of sight or hearing; it is all-pervading, extremely subtle, immutable, and is perceived as the origin of the universe by the wise.

sloka: tamādeśamaprākṣyaḥ yenāśrutaṃ śrutaṃ bhavati amataṃ mataṃ avijñātaṃ vijñātaṃ iti
translation: Unable to identify the source, something unheard becomes heard, the unknown is known, and the unrealized turns into realization.

sloka: prāṇabandhanaṃ hi mana
translation: The mind is indeed the binding factor of the life force.

sloka: sa ya eṣoṇimā aitadātmyamidam sarvaṃ tat satyam sa ātmā tattvamasi śvetaketo
translation: The one who truly understands this subtle self, which is the reality of all things, that self is the truth, O Śvetaketu.

sloka: krodhāyāḥ kanyakā jajñe dvādaśaivātmasaṃbhavāḥ | tā bhāryā pulahasyāsannāmato me nibodhata || || mṛgī ca mṛgamandā ca haribhadrā tvirāvatī | bhūtā ca kapiśā daṃṣṭrā ṛṣā tiryā tathaiva ca || || śvetā ca saramā caiva surasā ceti viśrutā | mṛgyāstu harigāḥ putrā mṛgaścānye śaśāstathā || ||
translation: The twelve offspring of Krodhā, born from the self of the Two-headed One, you should know are named as Pulahasa's wives. They are Mrigī, Mrgamandā, Haribhadrā, Tvirāvatī, Bhūtā, Kapiśa, and Daṃṣṭrā, Ṛṣā, Tiryā, Śvetā, Saramā, Surasā; the sons of Mṛgī are known as Mrigaya (the deer) and Harigā (the monkey), and others as Shaśa (the hare).

sloka: dullolakaṃ lalohaṃ ca saramā dvau vyajāyata || ||
translation: "The churning rod and fire produced two - the dollop of butter and the red ember."

sloka: viśve asyā vyuṣi māhināyāḥ saṃ yadgobhiraṅgiraso navanta utsa āsāṃ parame sadhastha ṛtasya pathā saramā vidadgāḥ
translation:
"All these movements of the vast universe, in unison with the unchanging rhythm,
flow along the finest channel of the ultimate truth."

sloka: anūnodatra hastayato adrirārcanyena daśa māso navagvāḥ | ṛtaṃ yatī saramā gā avindadviśvāni satyāṅgirāścakāra ||
translation: "For ten months, he offered oblations from his uplifted hands towards the admirable mountain. Sarama, the faithful dog of the truthful Angira, discovered the truth in all things."

sloka: sthūlaśarīraṃ kim ? pañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtaiḥ kṛtaṃ satkarmajanyaṃ sukhaduḥkhādibhogāyatanaṃ śarīram asti jāyate vardhate vipariṇamate apakṣīyate vinaśyatīti ṣaḍvikāravadetatsthūlaśarīram |
translation: The gross body, what is it? Made up of the five-fold modified great elements, born from past actions, the location for experiencing pleasure and pain, it grows, changes, decays, and ultimately dies.

sloka: sūkṣmaśarīraṃ kim ? apañcīkṛtapañcamahābhūtaiḥ kṛtaṃ satkarmajanyaṃ sukhaduḥkhādibhogasādhanaṃ pañcajñānendriyāṇi pañcakarmendriyāṇi pañcaprāṇādayaḥ manaścaikaṃ buddhiścaikā evaṃ saptadaśākalābhiḥ saha yattiṣṭhati tatsūkṣmaśarīram |
translation: The subtle body is made up of the five transformed great elements, accomplished through karma, the means to experience pleasure and pain; the five knowledge-acquiring senses, the five action senses, the five vital breaths, the mind, and the single intellect – all of which exist together with the seventeen constituents.

sloka: kāraṇaśarīraṃ kim ? anirvācyānādyavidyārūpaṃ śarīradvayasya kāraṇamātraṃ satsvarūpā'jñānaṃ nirvikalpakarūpaṃ yadasti tatkāraṇaśarīram |
translation: The cause of the two bodies (physical and subtle) is what? It is unutterable, beginningless ignorance. Its true nature is pure consciousness, free from all mental constructs. That is the causal body.

sloka: atha tatpūrvakaṃ trividhaṃ anumānaṃ pūrvavat śeṣavat sāmānyatodṛṣṭaṃ ca |||| {anumānalakṣaṇam}
translation: Then, in accordance with what was said before, there are three types of inference: based on the previous , based on the subsequent , and based on common characteristics .

sloka: tatpūrvakamityanena liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbandhadarśanaṃ liṅgadarśanaṃ cābhisaṃbadhyate | liṅgaliṅginoḥ saṃbadhdyordarśanena liṅgasmṛtirabhisaṃbadhyate | smṛtyā liṅgadarśanena cā'pratyakṣaḥ arthaḥ anumīyate |
translation: "Prior association of a sign with its signified is established through this connection. The recognition of a sign is also connected to the recognition of the signified. Through the perception of the connection between the sign and the signified, memory of the sign is established. And through remembering the sign, an unseen object is inferred."

sloka: prajñātena sāmānyātprajñāpanīyasya prajñāpanamupamānamiti | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya iti | yadā khalvayaṃ gavā samānadharmaṃ pratipadyate tadā pratyakṣatastamarthaṃ pratipadyata iti | samākhyāsambandhapratipattiḥ rūpamānārtha ityāha | yathā gaurevaṃ gavaya ityupamāne prayukte gavā samānadharmamarthamindriyārthasannikarṣādupalabhamāno asya gavayaśabdaḥ saṃjñeti saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyataiti | yathā mudgastathā mudgaparṇi yathā māṣastathā māṣapaṇi ityupamāne prayukte upamānāt saṃjñāsaṃjñisambandhaṃ pratipadyamānastāmoṣadhīṃ bhaiṣajyāyāharati | evamanyo apyupamānasya loke viṣayo bubhutsitavya iti |
translation: The designation of something as 'comprehended through general characteristics' is upheld as its definition. For instance, the term 'gavaya' (a type of animal) refers to that which shares similar attributes with a cow. When one understands the shared quality of this particular 'gavaya' with a cow, then at that moment, the true meaning becomes directly apparent. This is known as the relationship between a word and its intended meaning (saṃjñā-saṃjñisambandha). For example, when using the simile 'like a mudga' or 'like a mudga-leaf', one conveys the meaning of the original term through similarity, thus bringing forth the medicinal properties of the referred plant. Similarly, any object in the world can be understood and sought after based on such comparisons.

sloka: aāptaḥ khalu sākṣātkṛtadharmā yathādṛṣṭasyārthasya cikhyāpayiṣayā prayukta upadeṣṭā | sākṣātkaraṇamarthasya āptiḥ tayā pravarttata ityāptaḥ | ṛṣyāryyamlecchānāṃ samānaṃ lakṣaṇam |
translation: The appointed one, having directly realized the inherent nature of dharma and made known the meaning of what has been seen, is set in motion by that realization which is called 'aptitude'. This common characteristic applies to seers, noble ones, and outsiders alike.

sloka: pratyakṣānumānāgamāḥ pramāṇāni || ||
translation: The means of acquiring knowledge are perception, inference, and testimony.

sloka: tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti |
translation: There, the second is the Ṛgveda, Yajurveda, Sāmaveda, and Atharvaveda, along with Śikṣā, Kalpa, Vyākaraṇa, Nirukta, Chando, and Jyotiṣa.

sloka: tathā copapurāṇāni munibhiḥ kathitāni ca | mahāpurāṇānyetāni hyaṣṭādaśa mahāmune ||
translation: "Thus, also the ancillary Puranas have been mentioned by sages, and these eighteen Mahapuranas, O great sage."

sloka: yajanaṃ yājanaṃ caiva dānaṃ pātre pratigrahaḥ| adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ ṣaṭkarmā dharmabhāgṛjuḥ||
translation: Performing sacrifices, officiating at others’ sacrifices, giving with a clear conscience, accepting gifts in proper manner, teaching and studying are six meritorious acts.

sloka: satyaṃ dānaṃ kṣamā śīlamānṛśaṃsyaṃ tapo ghṛṇā | dṛśyante yatranāgendrasa brāhmaṇa iti smṛtaḥ ||
translation: Truthfulness, charity, forgiveness, sincerity, non-vanity, austerity, and compassion; these are recognized as the qualities of a brahmin.

sloka: adhyāpanam adhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaṃ caiva brāhmaṇānām akalpayat ||
translation: Conducting instructions, studying, performing sacrifices, officiating at sacrifices, giving and accepting (gifts), these were ordained for the brahmins.

sloka: ācāraḥ paramo dharmaḥ śrutyuktaḥ smārta eva ca | tasmādasminsadā yukto nityaṃ syādātmavāndvijaḥ ||
translation: The right conduct is the supreme duty, as declared in the scriptures and the traditions. Therefore, O wandering mendicant, one should always be absorbed in it, constantly engaged in self-reflection.

sloka: nākasya pṛṣṭhe adhi tiṣṭhati śrito yaḥ pṛṇāti sa ha deveṣu gacchati | tasmā āpo ghṛtamarṣanti sindhavastasmā iyaṃ dakṣiṇā pinvate sadā ||
translation: On the back of the sky dwells the one who nourishes, and he indeed enters into the gods; therefore, waters become fatty (nourishing) and the rivers always flourish.

sloka: sa tu dānasya tattvārthī tepe varṣagaṇānbahūn|| || ā āī ēē ṣṇāū|| || tatastaṃ prāha khe vāṇī ślokamekaṃ nṛpa śrṛṇu|| dvihetu ṣaḍadhiṣṭhānaṃ ṣaḍaṃgaṃ ca dvipākayuk|| || catuḥprakāraṃ trividhaṃ trināśaṃ dānamucyate||
translation: He, thoroughly understanding the true meaning of charity, endured heavy showers... Then, a celestial voice from the sky spoke a verse, listen, king: "There are six motives and six foundations for giving; it is classified as having three aspects and threefold destruction."

sloka: yujyante saṅklpyante sambadhyante parasparamarthāḥ samyaktayā prākaraṇike'bhimate'rthe virodhavyāghātādidoṣamapāsyānayā iti yuktiḥ yuj yojane tasmin yaktiriti rūpaṃ bhavati
translation: In synthesizing, uniting, and connecting with each other through proper means, abandoning contradictions, obstacles, and inherent faults for the sake of achieving the intended purpose, the form becomes 'yukti' in the act of joining or yoking.

sloka: yathā'mbujavanasyārkaḥ pradīpo veśmano yathā || prabodha prakāśārthāstathā tantrasya yuktayaḥ | ekasminnapi yasyeha śāstre labdāspadā matiḥ|| sa śāstramanyadapyāśu yuktijñatvāt prabudhyate |
translation: Like the sun is the illuminator of the cloud of the sky, so are the principles of a tantra (sacred text) the illuminator of its meaning. If in this scripture one finds the established basis of that meaning, they will instantly understand other scriptures through their comprehension of principles.

sloka: dharmamūlaṃ vedamāhuḥ grantharāśimakṛtrimam| tadvidāṃ smṛtiśīle ca sādhvācāraṃ manaḥpriyam ||
translation: The root of dharma is considered to be the Vedas, composed of many granthas (scriptures). For those who know this, proper conduct that is dear to the mind is established in the groove of smriti.

sloka: dṛṣṭo dharmavyatikramaḥ sāhasaṃ ca mahatāṃ || ̥ṣṭō ḥ āṁ āṁ || iti| sāhasaṃ paraśurāmādeḥ mātuḥ śirachedādi|
translation: Observed is Dharmavyadha's great courage, as well as Parashurama's, beginning with beheading his mother.

sloka: anānmāteṣu dharmeṣu kathaṃ syāditi cedbhavet | yaṃ śiṣṭā brāhṇā bhrūyuḥ sa dharmassyādaśāṅketaḥ|| | |
translation: "How could there be a norm in actions devoid of proper distinction, if not proclaimed by the wise brahmins?"

sloka: anānmāte daśāvaraiḥ śiṣṭaiḥ ūhavadbhiḥ alubdhaiḥ praśastaṃ kāryam| yattaiḥ praśastamityuktaṃ tatkāryamityarthaḥ|
translation: "The task assigned by trustworthy and impartial experts using proper words, which is declared as 'properly assigned', should be considered as such."

sloka: catvāro vedadharmajñāḥ pariṣatraividyameva vā| sā brūte yaṃ sa dharmassyādeko vā'dhyātmavittamaḥ||
translation: "The four knowers of the duties of the Vedas, (who are) thoroughly established in the knowledge of the supreme self, speak of that alone as dharma, whether it is one or many."

sloka: yenāsya pitaro yātāḥ yena yātāḥ pitāmahāḥ| tena yātātsatāṃ mārge tena gacchannariṣyati||
translation: By which his ancestors departed, by which also his great-grandfathers; he will proceed in that very path followed by the noble ones who have departed before him.

sloka: pramāṇato'rthapratipattau pravṛttisāmarththadarthavat pramāṇam | tasyepsājihāsāprayuktasya samīhā pravṛttirityucyate | dvayorekatarasya cāpi asannikṛṣṭārthaparicchittiḥ pramā tatsādhakatamaṃ yattattrividhaṃ pramāṇaṃ | sāṃkhyasūtra |
translation: For the establishment of the meaning of an object, a means of right knowledge is said to be efficient when it has the capacity to reveal the correct object. This efficient means of right knowledge is called "pravrtti" for the individual who is not joined with verbal communication (epasajihansa). Also, even in two out of the three kinds of right knowledge, when one aspect is not distinctly determined, that which makes it distinctly determined is said to be the most excellent means of right knowledge. This is the threefold means of right knowledge. *Sankhya Sutra*

sloka: agniṃ parisamūhya brahmacārī tūṣṇīṃ samidhamādadhyāt tūṣṇīṃ vai prājāpatyaṃ prājāpatyo brahmacārī bhavatīti vijñāyate
translation: After gathering fire-wood in silence, the Brahmachari silently offered the oblation to Fire; it is understood that the Brahmachari becomes identified with the all-pervading Lord Prajapati.

sloka: sa idbhojo yo gṛhave dadātyannakāmāya carate kṛśāya | aramasmai bhavati yāmahūtā utāparīṣu kṛṇute sakhāyam || balaṃ balavato naśyedannahīnasya dehinaḥ| tasmādannaṃ viśeṣeṇa śraddhayāśraddhayāpi vā|| ādatte hi rasaṃ sarvamādityaḥ svagabhastibhiḥ| vāyustasmātsamādāya rasaṃ megheṣu dhārayet|| tattu meghagataṃ bhūmau śakro varṣati tādṛśam| tena digdhā bhaveddevī mahī prītā ca bhārata|| tasyāṃ sasyāni rohanti yairjīvantyakhilāḥ prajāḥ| māṃsamedo'sthimajjānāṃ sambhavastebhya eva hi||
translation: The one who gives food to a needy person, not expecting anything in return, out of compassion for the weak and to create friendship, for such a person, that gift becomes nectar. Even if a strong person's physical strength is destroyed, it does not harm the powerless. Therefore, one should offer food with special devotion or even ordinary devotion. The sun extracts all taste from its own rays and the wind carries it upwards into the clouds. When Indra showers this downdrenched taste upon the earth, the earth becomes drenched with that taste and becomes pleased. Grains sprout from the earth which sustain all living beings. Similarly, the flesh, blood, and other bodily substances are produced only for them (grains etc.).

sloka: yanna prāpyaṃ tadaprāpyaṃ vidyayā pauruṣeṇa vā | satyo lokapravādo'yaṃ nādattamupatiṣṭhati ||
translation: "One cannot attain it without knowing it, nor can one stand firmly in this world without achieving it, through knowledge or effort. Such is the established saying."

sloka: na tasmātparamaṃ dānaṃ kiñcidastīti me manaḥ| annātprāṇabhṛtastāta pravardhante hi sarvaśaḥ|| tasmādannaṃ paraṃ loke sarvalokeṣu kathyate| annādbalaṃ ca tejaśca prāṇināṃ vardhate sadā||
translation: "There is nothing surpassing generosity, this is my conviction. From food, indeed, all beings derive their sustenance and grow in every way. Hence, in the world, food is considered the most excellent. From food, strength and vitality of living beings increase continuously."

sloka: asurāḥ paṇayo nāma rasāpāranivāsinaḥ | piveyaṃ tu payastāsāṃ gavāṃ yāstā niguhatha | asurāstāṃ tathetyuktvā tadājahuḥ payastataḥ sā svabhāvācca laulyācca pātvā tat paya āsuram |
translation: Demons, known as suppliers and dwellers of liquid preparations, should be offered the mixture of curd and ghee when making an offering to them. At that time, they said 'so be it' and drank up the mixture which was rightfully theirs due to both desire and nature.

sloka: śataṃ caikā hṛdasya nāḍyaḥ tāsāṃ mūrdhānamabhiniḥsṛtaikā tayordhvamāyannamṛtatvameti viṣvaṅṅanyā utkramaṇe bhavanti
translation: One hundred and one blood vessels of the heart, of which one emerges from the top; ascending through these, immortality is achieved; all others leave the body (at death).

sloka: janmanā brāhmaṇo jñeyaḥ saṃskārairdvija ucyate vidyayā yāti vipratvaṃ tribhiḥ śrotriyalakṣaṇam iti prāyaścittavivekaḥ
translation: A brahmin is to be known by birth, designated as dvija by rituals, attains vipra status through learning, and is characterized by the threefold qualities of a knower of the Vedas. This is the general understanding of the distinction regarding atonement.

sloka: dvividhā tu khalu tadvidyasaṃbhāṣā bhavati sandhāyasaṃbhāṣā vigṛhyasaṃbhāṣā ca |
translation: The expert's speech is of two kinds, related to sandhi (combining of words) and vitiation (faulty pronunciation).

sloka: tatra jñānavijñānavacanaprativacanaśaktisampannenākopenānupaskṛtavidyenānasūyakenānuneyenānunayakovidena kleśakṣameṇa priyasambhāṣaṇena ca saha sandhāyasambhāṣā vidhīyate |
translation: There, with a fully equipped [power of] knowledge, words, counter-words, and the power to convince; with the wise one who is free from envy, who seeks to elevate others, who knows the proper time for conveying knowledge, and who is skillful in pleasant conversation, a discussion is conducted.

sloka: jñānagrahaṇābhyāsastadvidyaiśca saha saṃvādaḥ || ||| taṃ śiṣyagurusabrahmacāriviśiṣṭaśreyo'rthibhiranasūyubhirabhyupeyāt || || pratipakṣahīnamapi vā prayojanārthamarthitve || ||
translation:
Practicing absorption of knowledge, conversing with those who are knowledgeable,
That, together with the teacher and brahmacāri, is considered the best means to attain supreme goals,
Free from envy and endowed with suitable means, even if it involves engaging with opponents for a purpose.

sloka: pramāṇatarkasādhanopālambhaḥ siddhāntāviruddhaḥ pañcāvayavopapannaḥ pakṣapratipakṣaparigrahaḥ vādaḥ ||||
translation: The method that is established based on reliable means of knowledge, consistent with the conclusion, having five limbs, and involving the consideration of both one's own and opposing viewpoints is known as debate.

sloka: sa jalpo vitaṇḍā bhavati kiṃ viśeṣaṇaḥ pratipakṣasthāpanayā hīnaḥ |
translation: That speech becomes a wrangle, but what's the point of pointing out its faults without proposing a counter-argument?

sloka: svapakṣarāgeṇa caike nyāyamativartante taca | tattvādhyavasāyasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ jalpavitaṇḍe bījaprarohasaṃrakṣaṇārthaṃ kaṇṭakaśākhāvaraṇavat || ||
translation: Some engage in logic using their own systems to protect the truth and maintain the integrity of their adherents' conviction, like protecting the growth of a planted seed by covering it with thorny branches.

sloka: anutpannatattvajñānānāmagrahīṇadoṣāṇāṃ tadarthe ghaṭamānānāmetaditi |
translation: Knowledge of unarisen reality's nature, devoid of the faults of not grasping all things, is what is being referred to as 'this' here.

sloka: budhajanairvādaḥ parityajyatām ||
translation: Reject, o gathering of the wise, this gathering (with me).

sloka: sampātirnāma nāmnā tu cirañjīvī vihaṅgamaḥ| bhrātā jaṭāyuṣaḥ śrīmānvikhyātabalapauruṣaḥ||||
translation: The long-lived bird named Sampati, renowned for his strength and vigor, is the brother of Jatayus.

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yannu ma iyaṃ bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te jīvitaṃ syāt amṛtatvasya tu nā''śā'sti vitteneti
translation: Maitreyi said to Yajnavalkya: "How can this, being so, make me immortal, since the whole earth even with all the wealth on it does not make me immortal?" Yajnavalkya replied: "Just as the life of temporary beings is, so will be your life. As for immortality, there is no means to attain it through wealth."

sloka: sā hovāca maitreyī yenāhaṃ nāmṛtā syāṃ kimahaṃ tena kuryām | yadeva bhagavānveda tadeva me brūhīti
translation: "Maitreyi said: 'By what means, sir, could I never be ungrateful? What should I do for that?' The Lord, please tell me whatever You know.'"

sloka: sa yathā saindhavakhilya udake prāsta udakevānuvilīyeta na hāsyodgrahaṇāyeva syāt yato yatastvādadīta lavaṇameva evaṃ vā ara idaṃ mahadbhūtamanantamapāraṃ vijñānaghana eva etebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya saṃjñāstotyare bravīmiti hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ
translation: Just as salt dissolves in a Sindhu (Indian Ocean) or any other water body, not remaining separate, similarly, this vast and infinite mass of knowledge, arising from these elements, merges back into them and does not retain its consciousness after death, Yajnavalkya said.

sloka: svīryateḥ vā | suvateḥ vā | sūryaḥ sarteḥ vā |
translation: Either from his own strength, or from good deeds, or from the sun's rays, one is warmed.

sloka: citraṃ devānāmudagādanīkaṃ cakṣurmitrasya varuṇasyāgneḥ | āprā dyāvāpṛthivī antarikṣaṃ sūrya ātmā jagatastasthuṣaśca ||
translation:
A marvel among the words of the gods is the eye of Mitra, Varuna, and Agni,
The heaven, earth, and atmosphere, and the sun are its self; such is the sustaining (sthusha) of the world.

sloka: yo'sau tapannudeti | sa sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇānādāyodeti | asau yo'stameti | sa sarveṣāṃ bhūtānāṃ prāṇānādāyāstametiṃ |
translation: The one who illuminates like fire, that one takes away and bestows the life-force of all beings; that one is called 'the giver' and 'the taker away' of the life-force of all beings.

sloka: avati trīnimā~llokān yasmātsūryaḥ paribhraman || avidhātuḥ prakāśākhyo hyavanātsa raviḥ smṛtaḥ || ||
translation: The sun, known as Prakashavidanath, illuminates the three worlds because of its motion, originating from Surya.

sloka: tat sūryasya devatvaṃ tanmahitvaṃ madhyā kartorvitataṃ saṃ jabhāra yadedayukta haritaḥ sadhasthādādrātrī vāsastanute simasmai
translation: The godhood of that (sun), its greatness, being the creator's midpoint, along with Harita and Dadhra, Aditi proclaims these to be the abode of this one.

sloka: ārogyaṃ bhāskarādiccheddhanamiccheddhutāśanāt | īśvarājjñānamicchecca mokṣamicchejjanārdanāt || ||
translation: Seek health from the sun's rays, dispeller of darkness and dampness; seek knowledge from the Lord, and liberation through the worship of Janardana (Vishnu).

sloka: sūryaḥ ātmā jaṅgamasya ca sthāvarasya ca | | |
translation: The sun is the inner self of both the moving and the non-moving.

sloka: ṛgbhiḥ pūrvāhṇe divi deva īyate | yajurvede tiṣṭhati | madhye ahnaḥ | sāmavedenāstamaye mahīyate | vedairaśūnyastribhireti sūryaḥ |
translation: At dawn, the god rises in the sky (Rigveda); at midday, he stands in the Yajurveda; in the afternoon, he rules over the earth in the Samaveda; and, devoid of the three Vedas, he sets (Surya).

sloka: dhruveṇādhiṣṭitaścaiva sūryo'po gṛhya varṣati || tadeṣa dīpta kiraṇaḥ sa kālagnirdivākaraḥ || || parivarttakramādviprā bhābhirālokayan diśaḥ || sūryaḥ kiraṇajālena vāyuyuktena sarvaśaḥ || || jagato jalamādatte kṛtsnasya dvijasattamāḥ || ādityapītaṃ sakalaṃ somaḥ saṃkramate jalam || ||
translation: By being established in Dhruva, the sun shines and rains. This is the fiery radiance of the sun, known as Kala-Agni (fire of time). It illuminates the directions with its revolving and changing lusters. The sun, along with its radiating rays and joined with the wind, permeates everything in the world. The best of the twice-born ones takes in the entire water of the world; Aditya (the sun) embraces all the water while Soma (the moon) transits it.

sloka: hriyanharistairharibhisturaṃgamairharatyathāpaḥ kiraṇairharidbhiḥ || visargakāle visṛjaṃśca tāḥ punarbibhartti śaśvatsavitā carācaram || ||
translation: The embodied beings, through their very own actions such as exuding lust, anger, and desire, cause the Lord of the beings to take birth. At the time of cosmic dissolution, these very elements are released again and again, sustaining the moving and non-moving entities in the universe.

sloka: suṣumno harikeśaśca viśvakarmā tathaiva ca | viśvaśravāḥ punaścānyaḥ saṃyadvasurataḥ paraḥ || arvāvasuriti khyātaḥ svarakaḥ sapta kīrtitāḥ | suṣumnaḥ sūryaraśmistu puṣṇāti śiśiradyutim ||
translation: Susumna, Harikesha, Visvakarma, and another one known as Samyadvasurata, as well as Arvavasuri and Svaraka, who are renowned as seven – of them, Susumna's solar rays nourish the cool splendor.

sloka: saṃsthitenaikacakreṇa paṃcāreṇa trinābhinā || hiraṇmayena bhagavāṃstathaiva haridarvaṇā || ||
translation: With a single, still wheel in the form of the pentad, O Golden One, thus also in the Darvahara manner.

sloka: sa tasya brahmaṇā sṛṣṭo ratho hyarthavaśena tu || asaṃgaḥ kāṃcano divyo yuktaḥ pavanagairhayaiḥ || ||
translation: Created by him through Brahma, the chariot is (of) that (divine) being, constructed by destiny, unsullied, sometimes equipped with divine winds as horses.

sloka: āvṛttā vālakhilyaiste bhramaṃte rātryahāni tu || vacobhiragryairgrathitaiḥ stūyamāno maharṣibhiḥ || ||
translation: "Spinning around are the Valkhilyas, day and night, praised by the great sages with foremost words."

sloka: vālakhilyā nayantyastaṃ parivāryodayād ravim |
translation: Valakhilyas illuminate that which has risen, dispelling the darkness of night.

sloka: ete tapanti varṣanti bhānti vānti sṛjanti ca | bhūtānāmaśubhaṃ karma vyapohantīha kīrttitāḥ || ete sahaiva sūryeṇa bhramanti divi bhānugāḥ | vimāne ca sthito nityaṃ kāmage vātaraṃhasi ||
translation: These radiate, rain, shine, and create . They are proclaimed to remove evil deeds of beings . These , along with the sun , move in the sky as planets . They always remain in the vehicle of desire .

sloka: sūryeṇa viṣuvaṃ vidyā tkālaṃ somena lakṣayet || samā rātrirahaścaiva yadā tadviṣuvaṃ bhavet || ||
translation: The duration of day and night should be determined by the sun, (and) the time of conjunction (of the moon with a star or constellation) should be calculated by the moon. The equalness (of days and nights) comes into being when it is the conjunction (of the sun with the equator).

sloka: devaliṅ‌gapraticchannaḥ svarbhānurdevasaṃsadi | praviṣṭaḥ somamapibat candrārkābhyāṃ ca sūcitaḥ || ||
translation:
Concealed by a divine body, entering the assembly of gods,
Indra, revealed by the moon and sun, partakes of soma.

sloka: sūtrārtho varṇyate yatra padai: sutrānusāribhiḥ| svapadāni ca varṇyante bhāṣyaṃ bhāṣyavido vidu: ||
translation: The meaning of aphorisms is explained using words and examples given by commentators, and the words themselves are also elaborated upon by knowledgeable scholars in their commentaries.

sloka: sumitriyā na ' āpa ' oṣadhayaḥ santu durmitriyās tasmai santu yo 'smān dveṣṭi yaṃ ca vayaṃ dviṣmaḥ ||
translation: Let no harmfull herbs be near Sumitra, but let them be near those who bear ill-will towards him, and also towards those whom we dislike.

sloka: ekaṃ sadviprā bahudhā vadantyagniṃ yamaṃ mātariśvānamāhuḥ ||
translation: "The sages call him by many names - one, Agni, Yama, and Matarisva."

sloka: saṃgaṭhana sūktam saṃvanana āṅgirasaḥ| agniḥ saṃjñānam| anuṣṭup triṣṭup| saṃsa॒midyṷvase vṛṣa॒nnagne॒ viśvā̭nya॒rya ā | i॒l̤aspa॒de sami̭dhyase॒ sa no॒ vasū॒nyā bha̭ra || saṃ ga̭cchadhva॒ṃ saṃ va̭dadhva॒ṃ saṃ vo॒ manā̭ṃsi jānatām | de॒vā bhā॒gaṃ yathā॒ pūrvḙ saṃjānā॒nā u॒pāsa̭te || sa॒mā॒no mantra॒: sami̭tiḥ samā॒nī sa̭mā॒naṃ mana̭: sa॒ha ci॒ttamḙṣām | sa॒mā॒naṃ mantra̭ma॒bhi ma̭ntraye vaḥ samā॒nena̭ vo ha॒viṣā̭ juhomi || sa॒mā॒nī va॒ ākṷ̄tiḥ samā॒nā hṛda̭yāni vaḥ | sa॒mā॒nama̭stu vo॒ mano॒ yathā̭ va॒: susa॒hāsa̭ti ||
jagrāha pāṭhyaṃ ṛgvedāt‌ sāmabhyo gītameva ca yajurvedādabhinayān‌ rasamātharvaṇādapi||
translation: He studied (grasped) the path of the Ṛgveda, specifically the hymns from the Sāma and the essence through the recitation of the Yajurveda, and likewise from the Atharvana.

sloka: sāmavedādidaṃ gītaṃ saṃjagrāha pitāmahaḥ
translation: The forefather adopted (this) song from the Saama Veda.

sloka: mātā bhūmiḥ putro'haṃ pṛthivyāḥ |
translation: I am the son of earth, the earth is my mother.

sloka: ṛṣyaśṛṅgastu jāmātā putrāṃstava vidhāsyati sanatkumārakathitametāvadvyāhṛtaṃ mayā
translation: The sage Shringi, indeed, will accomplish your sons as told by Sanatkumara. This is what has been revealed to me.

sloka: yathā mātaramāśritya sarve jīvanti jantavaḥ | tathā gṛhāśramaṃ prāpya sarve jīvanti cāśramāḥ||
translation: Just as all living beings flourish relying on their mothers, so do all residents thrive upon arriving at a proper abode.

sloka: upayuktaṃ ca yatteṣāṃ matimānnānuśocati || dharma ityeva saṅkalpya yastu tasya phalaṃ śṛṇu | sarvayajñapraṇītasya hayamedhena yatphalam | varṣe sa dvādaśe devi phalenaitena yujyate ||
translation: "Who is discerning and reflects upon what is fit to be done, having decided that it is dharma – listen to the result of such a person. The fruit of one who initiates all ritual actions, associated with horse sacrifice, is equal to the yield of a field in twelve years; this very yield is offered to the goddess during the annual rite."

sloka: śarīramekaṃ daṃpatyorvidhātrā pūrvanirmitam| tasmātsvadāranirato brahmacārī vidhīyate||
translation: The single physical body is created by the union of two factors. Therefore, a celibate student who is dedicated to his studies remains aloof from such engagement.

sloka: ekenāṃśena dharmārthaḥ kartavyo hitamicchatā| ekenāṃśena kāmārthamekamaṃśaṃ vivardhayet||
translation: "Dharma and artha should be pursued with a part [or fraction], desiring to benefit others; another part should be devoted to increasing kama."

sloka: saṃprāptāya tvatithaye pradadyādāsanodake | annaṃ caiva yathāśakti satkṛtya vidhipūrvakam | | | |
translation: For welcoming the arriving guest, one should offer a seat and water for washing feet, as well as food according to one's capacity, with due respect following proper procedures.

sloka: paradāreṣvasaṃsargo nyāsastrīparirakṣaṇam| adattādānaviramo madhumāṃsasya varjanam || eṣa pañcavidho dharmo bahuśākhaḥ sukhodayaḥ| dehibhirdharmaparamaiśrvartavyo dharmasambhavaḥ||
translation: Interaction with others' wives, neglecting one's own protection, not partaking of gifts given, and spurning honey-like food; these are the five types of unrighteousness that cause misery. This fivefold virtue, with many branches and leading to happiness, should be practiced by those seeking to attain righteousness and liberation.

sloka: yaḥ śāstravidhimutsṛjya vartate kāmakārataḥ | na sa siddhimavāpnoti na sukhaṃ na parāṃ gatim || tasmācchāstraṃ pramāṇaṃ te kāryākāryavyavasthitau | jñātvā śāstravidhānoktaṃ karma kartumihārhasi ||
translation:
One who abandons scriptural rules and acts according to his whims,
Does not attain success, happiness, or the highest goal.
Therefore, scripture is your authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done.
Having known the scripturally ordained duty, you should be eager to perform it.

sloka: sattvaṃ sukhe saṃjayati rajaḥ karmaṇi bhārata | jñānamāvṛtya tu tamaḥ pramāde saṃjayatyuta ||
translation: The sattva (purity, knowledge) becomes established in happiness, rajas (passion, activity) in action, O Bharata; and tamas (inertia, ignorance), covered by ignorance, becomes prominent in confusion.

sloka: yajante sāttvikā devānyakṣarakṣāṃsi rājasāḥ | pretānbhūtagaṇāṃścānye yajante tāmasā janāḥ ||
translation: The virtuous worship deities, while the passionate worship nature spirits; and the deluded, ghosts and ancestral spirits.

sloka: aśāstravihitaṃ ghoraṃ tapyante ye tapo janāḥ | dambhāhaṃkārasaṃyuktāḥ kāmarāgabalānvitāḥ || karṣayantaḥ śarīrasthaṃ bhūtagrāmamacetasaḥ | māṃ caivāntaḥśarīrasthaṃ tānviddhyāsuraniścayān ||
translation: Those who practise terrible austerities not prescribed by the scriptures, driven by arrogance and desire, tormenting their own body and the group of elements within, as well as me who is established within that body – consider them to be of demonic resolve.

sloka: oṃtatsaditi nirdeśo brahmaṇastrividhaḥ smṛtaḥ | brāhmaṇāstena vedāśca yajñāśca vihitāḥ purā ||
translation: "The word 'om tatsad' is considered as threefold indication of Brahman, through which were indicated earlier the Brahmins and the Vedas and the Yajnas."

sloka: aśraddhayā hutaṃ dattaṃ tapastaptaṃ kṛtaṃ ca yat | asadityucyate pārtha na ca tatpretya no iha ||
translation: "Offered without faith, charity, austerities, and actions, O Partha, are called Asat (unreal) and have no lasting impact in this life or the afterlife."

sloka: uśanha vai vājaśravasaḥ sarvavedasaṃ dadau
translation: Ushanaha, also known as Vajashravasa, donated all knowledge in the sacrifice.

sloka: pītodakā jagdhatṛṇā dugdhadohā nirindriyāḥ
translation: Drinking water, treading on the ground, milking the udder of the cow, devoid of senses (i.e., inanimate)...

sloka: sa hovāca pitaraṃ tata kasmai māṃ dāsyasīti
translation: He asked his father, "To whom would you give me?"

sloka: bahūnāmemi prathamo bahūnāmemi madhyamaḥ |
translation: I am the first among many, I am also the middle among many.

sloka: anupaśya yathā pūrve pratipaśya tathā pare | sasyamiva martyaḥ pacyate sasyamivājāyate punaḥ || ||
translation: Observe how earlier (events) have passed, similarly observe those that will come; like a crop, a person gets cooked (dies), like a crop, they are reborn again.

sloka: devairatrāpi vicikitsitaṃ purā na hi suvijñeyamaṇureṣa dharmaḥ |
translation: "This law has been pondered upon even by the gods in the past, and is still not easily understood."

sloka: śāśvatī śabalā mahyaṃ kīrtirātmagato yathā asyāṃ havyaṃ ca kavyaṃ ca prāṇayātrā tathaiva ca
translation: My fame, strength and wealth are eternal like my own self; similarly, in this (body) the oblation, poetry, and life's journey are also equally eternal.

sloka: brāhmaṇo'sya mukhamāsīdbāhū rājanyaḥ kṛtaḥ | ūrū tadasya yadvaiśyaḥ padbhyāṃ śūdro ajāyata ||
translation: The brahmin was born from his mouth, the ruler from his arms, the vaishya from his thighs, and the shudra from his feet.

sloka: sarvasyāsya tu sargasya guptyarthaṃ sa mahādyutiḥ | mukhabāhūrupajjānāṃ pṛthakkarmāṇyakalpayat | | | |
translation: For the protection of all that exists, he of great brilliance created separate actions for those with mouths, arms, and feet.

sloka: brāhmaṇānāṃ sito varṇaḥ kṣatriyāṇāṃ tu lohitaḥ | vaiśyānāṃ pītako varṇaḥ śūdrāṇāmasitastathā || ||
translation: The color of brahmins is white, while that of kshatriyas is red. The color of vaishyas is yellow, and that of shudras is also black.

sloka: na viśeṣo'stivarṇānāṃ sarve brāhmamidaṃ jagat | brahmaṇā pūrvasṛṣṭaṃ hi karmabhirvarṇatāṃ gatam || ||
translation: There is no distinction between various colors, indeed, this entire universe is Brahman; through actions, it has become diverse in appearance.

sloka: kāmabhogapriyāstīkṣṇāḥ krodhanāḥ priyasāhasāḥ | tyaktvasvadharmāraktāṅgāste dvijāḥ kṣatratāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Fond of sensual pleasures, sharp, wrathful, and fond of speaking sweet words, they, having abandoned their own dharmas, have become warriors.

sloka: gobhyo vṛttiṃ samāsthāya pītāḥ kṛṣyupajīvinaḥ | svadharmān nānutiṣṭhanti te dvijā vaiśyatāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Cattle rearers, establishing their livelihood in this way, do not follow their own duties; indeed, they have fallen to the level of vaishyas.

sloka: hiṃsānṛtapriyā lubdhāḥ sarvakarmopajīvinaḥ | kṛṣṇāḥ śaucaparibhraṣṭāste dvijāḥ śūdratāṃ gatāḥ || ||
translation: Those who are violent, delight in falsehood, greedy, and live off of all kinds of activities; who are sinful, have fallen from purity, and behaved improperly - they, the once-brāhmaṇas, have become śūdras.

sloka: ityetaiḥ karmabhirvyastā dvijā varṇāntaraṃ gatāḥ | dharmo yajñakriyā teṣāṃ na nityaṃ na pratiṣidhyate || ||
translation: "Thus, having performed these actions, the twice-born have crossed the social boundaries. Their duty and ritual worship do not remain permanent or consistently established."

sloka: śreyānsvadharmo viguṇaḥ paradharmātsvanuṣṭhitāt | svadharme nidhanaṃ śreyaḥ paradharmo bhayāvahaḥ || ||
translation: It is better to perform one's own duty (swadharma), even if imperfectly, than to perform another's duty perfectly. Death in one's own duty is preferable; performing another's duty leads to danger.

sloka: varaṃ svadharmo viguṇo na pārakyaḥ svanuṣṭhitaḥ | paradharmeṇa jīvanhi sadyaḥ patati jātitaḥ | | | |
translation: "It is better to perform one's own duties, even if imperfectly, than to perfectly perform another's duties. By performing his own duties, a person does not incur sin; by abandoning them and performing another's duties, he inevitably falls."

sloka: kadū mahīradhṛṣṭā asya taviṣīḥ kadu vṛtraghno astṛtam | indro viśvānbekanāṭā~ ahardṛśa uta kratvā paṇī~rabhi ||
translation: When will (kadū) the earth-lord (mahīradhṛṣṭā), triumphant (dhṛṣṭā) over his enemies (vṛtraghno), be willing (asya taviṣīḥ kadu) to shake (indro viśvānbekanāṭā) hard (ahardṛśa) with his prowess (kratu) and expansive power (paṇīrabhi)?

sloka: vadhīrhi dasyuṃ dhaninaṃ ghanena~ ekaścarannupaśākebhirindra | dhanoradhi viṣuṇakte vyāyannayajvānaḥ sanakāḥ pretimīyuḥ ||
translation: The mighty (vadhīrhi) Indra, alone (ekaśca), with his thunderbolt (ghanaena), annihilates (vyāyan + ni + √han) the wealthy (dhaninaṃ) Dasyu; his (sana) arrows (dhanoradhi), like snakes (viṣuṇakte), eagerly (pretimīyuḥ) rush towards (anupaśākebhirindra).

sloka: apāma somamamṛtā abhūmāganma jyotiravidāma devān | kiṃ nūnamasmānkṛṇavadarātiḥ kimu dhūrtiramṛta martyasya ||
translation: "The divine ones have become immortal, tasting the drink that was Soma. What sin or harm can possibly affect us, O mortals?"

sloka: tasyāśitādyādāhārādbalaṃ varṇaśca vardhate yasyartusātmyaṃ viditaṃ ceṣṭāhāravyapāśrayam
translation: The strength and complexion of that (being) who knows the inherent nature of its consumer and engages in eating, grow from the food.

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: One who follows proper lifestyle, possesses good memory, intelligence, sound health, youthfulness, bright complexion, pleasant voice, respectability, and strength of body and senses obtains these through the use of (proper) sustenance, not from ineffective elixirs.

sloka: ṛtvorantyādisaptāhāvṛtusandhiriti smṛtaḥ tatra pūrvo vidhistyājyaḥ sevanīyo'paraḥ kramāt asātmyajā hi rogāḥ syuḥ sahasā tyāgaśīlanāt
translation: The ṛtvik (priest) who performs the specified duties in their proper order, is to be first honored and then served. Neglecting or abandoning these duties leads to rapid onset of diseases, as they are caused by imbalance.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation: The three causes of physical transformations are the improper combination with sense-objects, intellectual mistakes, and the natural disposition; these are of three kinds each.

sloka: kālārthakarmaṇāṃ yogo hīnamithyātimātrakaḥ| samyagyogośca vijñeyo rogārogyaikakāraṇam||
translation: The yoga of deed aimed at temporal gains is insufficient; truly know yoga to be proper use, the single cause of both disease and health.

sloka: dhīdhṛtismṛtivibhraṣṭaḥ karma yatkurute aśubham| prajñāparādhaṃ taṃ vidyāt sarvadoṣaprakopaṇam||
translation: One who acts with negligence, having abandoned mindfulness and retention, should know that such an action is inauspicious and a transgression of wisdom, capable of causing the eruption of all faults.

sloka: daivamātmakṛtaṃ vidyāt karma yat paurvadaihikam smṛtaḥ puruṣakārastu kriyate yadihāparam
translation: The action that is born from previous lives' deeds is considered as made by the self, while the one created now is attributed to human effort.

sloka: atīndriyaṃ punarmanaḥ sattvasañjñakaṃ ‘cetaḥ’ ityāhureke tadarthātmasampadāyattaceṣṭaṃ ceṣṭāpratyayabhūtamindriyāṇām
translation: The term 'cetah' refers to the self-aware aspect of the mind, which is beyond the senses and indicates the presence of pure consciousness. Its manifestation as an act is called 'ceshta', resulting from a matured state of the sattvva guna.

sloka: cintyaṃ vicāryamūhyaṃ ca dhyeyaṃ saṅkalpyameva ca yatkiñcinmanaso jñeyaṃ tat sarvaṃ hyarthasañjñakam indriyābhigrahaḥ karma manasaḥ svasya nigrahaḥ ūho vicāraśca
translation: Worth pondering, a subject of reflection, and that which is to be meditated upon, as well as resolved by the mind, whatever is knowable by the mind, all of it is simply a designation of meaning, a grasping of the objects by the senses, controlling one's own actions and thoughts. This is the process of examination (vicara).

sloka: sparśanendriyasaṃsparśaḥ sparśo mānasa eva ca dvividhaḥ sukhaduḥkhānāṃ vedanānāṃ pravartakaḥ
translation: The contact between the sense organ and its object is also twofold: mental and physical, as it gives rise to experiences of pleasure and pain.

sloka: vedanānāmadhiṣṭhānaṃ mano dehaśca sendriyaḥ keśalomanakhāgrānnamaladravaguṇairvinā
translation: The basis of feelings is the mind, and the body along with the senses are not subtle qualities such as lustrousness and lightness without.

sloka: tatrendriyāṇāṃ samanaskānāmanupataptānāmanupatāpāya prakṛtibhāve prayatitavyamebhirhetubhiḥ
translation: The coming together of the senses and their objects, and withdrawal from them, is due to the inherent nature (prakriti) of the elements (hetu).

sloka: yaccāpriyamapathyaṃ ca niyataṃ tanna lakṣayet
translation: Should not be constantly considered as enjoyable or pleasurable that which is not dear/agreeable.

sloka: mṛjyate śodhyate iti |
translation: Gets cleaned, gets purified.

sloka: tatra śarīraṃ nāma cetanādhiṣṭhānabhūtaṃ pañcamahābhūtavikārasamudāyātmakaṃ samayogavāhi
translation: The body, named as such, is composed of the combination of the five great elements and is the abode of consciousness.

sloka: yadā hyasmiñ śarīre dhātavo vaiṣamyamāpadyante tadā kleśaṃ vināśaṃ vā prāpnoti
translation: When the imbalance occurs in the bodily constituents , then one experiences either suffering or its cessation .

sloka: kārtsnyena śarīravṛdhdikarāstvime bhāvā bhavanti
translation: "Extreme exertion towards the body results in the manifestation of distinct states."

sloka: sarve śarīradoṣā bhavanti grāmyāhārāt|
translation: All physical ailments arise from unwholesome food.

sloka: tatra vaikārikādahaṅkārāttaijasasahāyāttallakṣaṇānyevaikādaśendriyāṇyutpadyante tadyathā śrotratvakcakṣurjihvāghrāṇavāgghastopasthapāyupādamanāṃsīti
translation: There, the eleven sense organs, characterized by distinct qualities, arise from the combination of the ego-based on subtle elements and the intellect: hearing, touch, sight, taste, smell, speech, and the organs of evacuation, grasping, locomotion, and excretion.

sloka: manaḥpuraḥsarāṇīndriyāṇyarthagrahaṇasamarthāni bhavanti
translation: The faculties of the mind, located in the heart, become capable of grasping objects.

sloka: sendriyaṃ cetanaṃ dravyaṃ nirindriyamacetanam
translation: The senses-related , conscious , substance , and the non-senses related, unconscious

sloka: taddhyanutiṣṭhan yugapat sampādayatyarthadvayamārogyamindriyavijayaṃ ceti
translation: Engaging in that meditation, simultaneously brings about the accomplishment of two things - freedom from disease and mastery over the senses.

sloka: brahmacaryajñānadānamaitrīkāruṇyaharṣopekṣāpraśamaparaśca syāditi
translation: The qualities of a student of sacred knowledge include celibacy, charity, self-knowledge, friendship, compassion, joy, equanimity, and serenity.

sloka: āyurasmin vidyate anena vā āyurvindanti iti āyurvedaḥ |
translation: The knowledge that either preserves life or increases its duration is called Ayurveda.

sloka: hitāhitaṃ sukhaṃ duḥkham āyus tasya hitāhitam | mānaṃ ca tacca yatroktam āyurvedaḥ sa ucyate ||
translation: "That which concerns itself with promoting benefit, preventing harm, happiness, sorrow, life span, and dignity is called Ayurveda."

sloka: dharmārthakāmamokṣāṇāmārogyaṃ mūlam uttamam || rogāstasyāpahartāraḥ śreyaso jīvitasya ca | prādurbhūto manuṣyāṇāmantarāyo mahānayam ||
translation: The root cause of dharma, artha, kama, and moksha is good health; it is the foremost means of removing diseases and promoting well-being. This great internal medicine has become widely prevalent among human beings.

sloka: satvamātmā śarīraṃ ca trayametattridaṇḍavat | lokstiṣṭhati saṃyogāttatra sarvaṃ pratiṣṭhitam | sa pumāṃścetanaṃ tacca taccādhikaraṇaṃ smrutam | vedasyāsya tadarthaṃ hi vedo ayaṃ prakāśitaḥ ||
translation: The self , the physical body , and the consciousness are likened to a tripod. This whole world rests on their union; everything is established upon them. The individual being , cognizance , and the basis of that cognizance are remembered. Indeed, the purpose of this Veda is to reveal the meaning of this very entity.

sloka: tadidaṃ śāśvataṃ puṇyaṃ svargyaṃ yaśasyamāyuṣyaṃ vṛttikaraṃ ceti ||
translation: That indeed is eternal, sacred, heavenly, famous, long-lasting, and productive.

sloka: dhātusāmyakriyā coktā tantrasyāsya prayojanam ||
translation: The purpose of this tantra is to explain the harmonious functioning of the constituents (or principles).

sloka: iha khalvāyurvedaprayojanaṃ vyādhyupasṛṣṭānāṃ vyādhiparimokṣaḥ svasthasya rakṣaṇaṃ ca ||
translation: Indeed, the purpose of Ayurveda in this world is the elimination of diseases in those who are afflicted and the protection of health in the healthy.

sloka: sirāsnāyurajaḥstanyatvaco gativivarjitāḥ| dhātubhyaścopajāyante tasmātta upadhātavaḥ ||
translation: "From sweat, hair, nails, teeth, and bones, which are free from decay, devoid of bad qualities, and born from bodily tissues, one should understand these as secondary products (upadhātavaḥ)."

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|–
translation: The knowledge of particulars about diseases is threefold: it is through scriptural reference, perception, and inference.

sloka: prāgabhihitaṃ taddu:khasaṃyogāḥ vyādhayaḥ iti| tacca duḥkhaṃ trividhaṃ ādhyātmikam ādhidaivikam ādhibhautikamiti|
translation: Previous instructions, referred to as dukhasamyogah, are threefold types of afflictions called adhyatmikam, adhidaivikam, and adhibhautikam, causing suffering.

sloka: jāyate buḍhheravyaktādbuddhyā ahm iti manyante| paraṃ khādīnyahaṅkārādutpadyante yathākramam||
translation: "From the unmanifest, consciousness arises; they think 'it is I'. Subsequently, egoistic feelings arise one after another."

sloka: avyaktaṃ mahānahaṅkāraḥ pancatanmātrāṇi ścetyaṣṭau prakṛtayaḥ śeṣāḥ ṣoḍaśa vikārāḥ|
translation: The unmanifest is the great self-consciousness, along with the five subtle elements, making eight fundamentals; followed by sixteen transformations.

sloka: sarvadā sarvabhāvānāṃ sāmānyaṃ vṛddhikāraṇam| hrāsaheturviśeṣaśca pravṛttirubhayasya tu||
translation: The increase of the general (common characteristic) is always nourishment for all beings, while particularity (specific feature) acts as their cause of decay, andpravrtti (activity) is common to both.

sloka: jāṭhareṇāgnināyogāt yadudeti rasāntaram| rasānāṃ pariṇāmānte sa vipākaḥ iti smṛtaḥ||–
translation: The transformation that occurs when an internal fire (agni) is set in motion in the digestive system, causing the separation and transformation of different types of food, is known as vipāka.

sloka: śarīrāvayavāstu paramāṇubhedenāparisaṅkhyeyā bhavanti atibahutvādatisaukṣmyādatīndriyatvācca teṣāṃ saṃyogavibhāge paramāṇūnāṃ kāraṇaṃ vāyuḥ karmasvabhāvaśca
translation: The constituents of the body, due to their infinite divisibility into fundamental units (paramānu), are incredibly numerous, minute, and beyond sensory perception. The arrangement and disarrangement of these fundamental units is caused by the properties of the elemental force, viz., wind (vāyu).

sloka: trividham khalu rogaviṣeśavijñānam bhavati tad yathā āptopadeśaḥ pratyakṣaṃ anumānaṃ ceti|–
translation: The knowledge of particulars about diseases is threefold: it comes from reliable instruction, perception, and inference.

sloka: pratyakṣaṃ hyalpam
translation: This is directly perceptible, though small. (Referring to something that is barely visible but still detectable by direct perception.)

sloka: athaupamyam aupamyaṃnāmayadanyenānyasyasādṛśyamadhikṛtyaprakāśanaṃ
translation: Comparable to the incomparable, revealing what is unlike anything else.

sloka: pūrvajanmakṛtaṃ pāpaṃ vyādhirupeṇa bādhyate ||
translation: Past life demerits manifest as diseases.

sloka: yāvantāḥ loke mūrtimantaḥ bhāvaviśeṣāḥ tāvantāḥ puruṣe yāvantāḥ puruṣe tāvantāḥ loke ||
translation: "In this world, whatever distinct forms exist, so many there are in Purusha (the cosmic being). And whatever is the count of such forms within Purusha, the same is the count in this world."

sloka: dīrghamāyuḥ smṛtiṃ medhāmārogyaṃ taruṇaṃvayaḥ prabhāvarṇasvaraudāryaṃ dehendriyabalaṃ param vāksiddhiṃ praṇatiṃkāntiṃ labhate nā rasāyanāt lābhopāyo hi śastānāṃ rasādīnāṃ rasāyanam
translation: One who practices self-control, proper diet, hygiene, and exercise, as well as respects and honors others, acquires a long life, good memory, excellent health, youthfulness, bright complexion, pleasant speech, and physical and mental strength. This is not the result of taking elixirs or drugs, but rather the reward for those who follow the path of restraint.

sloka: cikitsā ruk pratikriyā|
translation: Treatment or therapeutic measure (is) the counteraction/opposite measure.

sloka: yābhiḥ kriyābhirjāyante śarīre dhātavaḥ samāḥ sā cikitsā vikārāṇāṃ karma tadbhiṣajāṃ smṛtam kathaṃ śarīre dhātūnāṃ vaiṣamyaṃ na bhavediti samānāṃ cānubandhaḥ syādityarthaṃ kriyate kriyā
translation: The actions through which the same tissue elements are generated in the body, and the treatment, which is remembered as the function of those healers, is considered to be the cause that prevents the disparity of bodily tissues and promotes their harmony.

sloka: caturṇāṃ bhiṣagādīnāṃ śastānāṃ dhātuvaikṛte pravṛttirdhātusāmyārthā cikitsetyabhidhīyate
translation: The distinct functioning of the four healers - caused by a single root , is called having equal effect in curing .

sloka: apyevaṃ tu bhavet puṣpaṃ phalenānanubandhi yat | phalaṃ cāpi bhavet kiñcidyasya puṣpaṃ na pūrvajam || na tvariṣṭasya jātasya nāśo'sti maraṇādṛte | maraṇaṃ cāpi tannāsti yannāriṣṭapuraḥsaram||
translation: "Just as a flower and its fruit are connected, if there is a flower, there will be some fruit. For one who is hasty, there is no destruction before death, and for him, there is also no death, for he is the supreme imperishable."

sloka: mithyādṛṣṭamariṣṭābhamanariṣṭamajānatā ariṣṭaṃ vā'pyasambuddhametat prajñāparādhajam
translation: Perceiving the unreal as real, not knowing what is truly auspicious; even what is inauspicious, when mistakenly recognized, arises from the mistake of the mind.

sloka: dūṣayanti iti doṣāḥ
translation: "are called faults" or "are considered as faults"

sloka: vāyuḥ pittaṃ kaphaścoktaḥ śārīro doṣasaṅgrahaḥ
translation: The three doshas are said to be wind (Vayu), bile (Pitta), and phlegm (Kapha) in the body.

sloka: mānasaḥ punaruddiṣṭo rajaśca tama eva ca
translation: Of the mind, (there are) re-emergence and withdrawal, (which are) like royalty and darkness (respectively).

sloka: maitrī kāruṇyamārteṣu śakye prītirupekṣaṇam prakṛtistheṣu bhūteṣu vaidyavṛttiścaturvidheti
translation: Friendliness towards all beings, compassion for those in distress, gladness in the prosperity of others, and indifference towards those who cause harm; these are the four practices of a true physician.

sloka: hetau liṅge praśamane rogāṇāmapunarbhave jñānaṃ caturvidhaṃ yasya sa rājārho bhiṣaktamaḥ
translation: The ruler who possesses fourfold knowledge, capable of calming down conflicts through conciliation and using the tool (of punishment), and preventing the recurrence of disease, is the best healer.

sloka: dharmasyārthasya kāmasya nṛlokasyobhayasya ca dātā sampadyate vaidyo dānāddehasukhāyuṣām
translation: The physician becomes the giver of dharma's fruit, wealth's purpose, desire's fulfillment, and the world of men's dual prosperity and longevity.

sloka: ruk vedanāyāyām|
translation: In a state of pain.

sloka: nidāna pūrvarūpāṇi rupāṇyupaśayastathā saṃprāptiśceti vijñānaṃ rogāṇāṃ pañcadhā smṛtam|
translation: The five types of knowledge about diseases are recognized as: initial symptoms, manifestation of the disease, and its predisposing factors, as well as its establishment.

sloka: tatra vikāraṃ hetudoṣadūṣyaprakṛtideśakālabalaviśeṣairliṅgataśca parīkṣeta na hyantareṇa hetvādīnāṃ balaviśeṣaṃ vyādhibalaviśeṣopalabdhiḥ
translation: In that case, one should examine the cause of change as due to unwholesome qualities, time, place, and individual strength; not by comparing the mere strength of causes, but by observing the superior strength of the disease.

sloka: asātmyendriyārthasaṃyogaḥ prajñāparādhaḥ pariṇāmaśceti trayastrividhavikalpā hetavo vikārāṇāṃ samayogayuktāstu prakrutihetavo bhavanti |
translation:
The three causes of the transformation of the guṇas are: 
1. the union of the senses with unwholesome objects,
2. a mistake in understanding, and
3. the natural cause.

sloka: kālārthakarmaṇāṃ yogo hīnamithyātimātrakaḥ| samyagyogośca vijñeyo rogārogyaikakāraṇam||
translation: The yoga of fruitless actions for time is merely a wasted effort; proper yoga should be known as the cause of both disease and health.

sloka: te caturvidhāḥ āgantavaḥ śārīrāḥ mānasāḥ svābhāvikāśceti
translation: They are fourfold - corporal and mental, naturally occurring.

sloka: dhāraṇāt dhātavaḥ
translation: Through concentration comes the formation of the elements .

sloka: dhātavaḥ punaḥ śārīrāḥ samānaguṇaiḥ samānaguṇabhūyiṣṭhairvā'pyāhāravikārairabhyasyamānairvṛddhiṃ prāpnuvanti hrāsaṃ tu viparītaguṇairviparītaguṇabhūyiṣṭhairvā'pyāhārairabhyasyamānaiḥ||
translation: The bodily tissues regain growth through similar qualities that are equally preeminent , as well as through the same kinds of transformations ; however, they undergo destruction through qualities that are opposite and excessively preeminent , as well as through transformations that are opposite .

sloka: strīpuṃsayoravyāpannaśukraśoṇitagarbhāśayayoḥ śreyasīṃ prajāmicchatostadarthābhinirvṛttikaraṃ karmopadekṣyāmaḥ
translation: Of the two bodies of a man and woman, united in the act of love, we approve that action which leads to the welfare of the offspring.

sloka: tasyāmanupaghātāya paripūrṇatvāya sukhaprasavāya ca
translation: For its complete protection, fulfillment, and for the easy emergence of happiness.

sloka: dhruvaṃ caturṇāṃ sānnidhyādgarbhaḥ syādvidhipūrvakam ṛtukṣetrāmbubījānāṃ sāmagryādaṅkuro yathā
translation: The meeting of four (components) certainly gives rise to the embryo in a manner prescribed by ritual, just as the sprout emerges from the union of earth, water, and time.

sloka: dve vidye veditavye iti h sma yadbrahmavido vadanti parā caivāparā ca tatrāparā ṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvavedaḥ śikṣā kalpo vyākaraṇaṃ niruktaṃ chando jyotiṣamiti atha parā yayā tadakṣaramadhigmyate
translation: "The scholars of Brahman say that there are two types of knowledge to be known. One is the lower and the other is the higher. The four Vedas, phonetics, ritual, grammar, etymology, meter, and astrology comprise the lower knowledge. The higher knowledge is that by which the imperishable (the Brahman) is known."
